review:
Sugar’s debut LP, from 1978: inspired, crafted voicings of all-time classic rhythms, defiantly announcing the rebirth of the greatest reggae label of all time, with vibes and panache to the max.
UK pressing.

label: Uptempo
review: An LP’s worth of vintage Studio One rhythms (and Coxsone productions), vocals plus dubs, all unavailable elsewhere.

label: Revolutionary Sounds
review: Moody, revolutionary-minded, beautifully-crafted by Donovan Germain. Great Sugar.

label: Dug Out
review: Co-architect of Black Victory, Sugar himself takes the mic for its last release, a driving sufferers cliffhanger about bent cops and going on the run, with Bagga Walker, the great Studio One bassist, in full effect.

label: Archive
review: Top-quality, previously-unreleased Sugar, in fine voice at Joe Gibbs. Strong rhythm, too, rich and moody.

label: SMP
review: Biff! Knockout Sugar Booger Minott. Ace mid-eighties co-production with Bertie ‘Stamma’ Grant (whose Omega Studios in London was more accustomed to turning out Lovers — Jean Adebambo, Carol Thompson and co — at this time). Killer bubblers, with a sick dub. Another Shaka weapon bites the dust.

label: Preacher Cleavie Jefferey / Jah Fingers
review:
Vintage UK digital, animated by Sugar; a Shaka tune in the day.
(A bit disappointingly, Preacher Cleavie Jefferey is three men: producers Preacher, Cleveland Neunie and Jeffrey Beckford.)

label: Studio One / Dub Store
review: Sublimely versioning the almighty Curtis anthem; with another rocksteady clarion-call on the flip, brassy and more stern, by The Hamlins.

label: Merritone / Dub Store
review: Pure loveliness from 1967 — with an acappella version.

label: Basic Replay
review: An apocalyptic record, full of dread — dubwise and deep from the first interstellar chords, over Wackies-style steppers drum and bass — with a dream-like atmosphere of pain and sufferation, mystery and redemption.

artist: Jackie Mittoo And The Soul Brothers
label: Soul Jazz
review: ‘The Soul Brothers possess a Crystal Clear Sound. Obviously it would be better to Cut the Chatter and Spin the Platter.’ Instrumentals by the awesome Studio One house band led by Jackie Mittoo and Roland Alphonso, 1965-67.

release: The Keyboard King At Studio One
label: Universal Sound
review: An excellent introduction — top selection across styles and vintages, well paced, and with some marvellous photographs of Jackie at Kingston airport, Canada bound.

label: Studio One
review: A rare Mittoo, backed with a sublime version of the Curtis.

artist: Jackie Mittoo And The Soul Brothers
label: Supreme / Dub Store
review: Tough pan-Caribbean wig-out, complete with twanging guitar and characteristically hot organ; plus The Jamaicans’ lovely version of the Sam Cooke.

label: Digikiller
review: Dubplate, deejay piece to Fulk Reid’s Golden Daffodils (itself put back till the next batch of Digikillers, because of manufacturing problems). Mojo Blue aka Jah Mojo, from Santic.

label: Wackies
review:
From the last wave of Digikiller reissues, but so nice we up it twice. 
Terrific, deep, mystical roots, protesting the imprisonment of Desmond Trotter for the 1974 murder of a US tourist in Domenica. (Trots was fingered by a young lady from Antigua called Pretty Pig, the court was told.) 
Originally released on the Jumbo Caribbean Disco label run by Brooklyn’s African Record Center shop. Discomixes, both sides.
Don’t miss it.

label: Kentone / Dub Store
review: Opportunity knocking once. Mid-tempo doowop-ska. On the flip, the Sneer Towners, hardly a household name themselves.

label: Digikiller
review: Ace, quirky one-away — effervescent singing on a bubbling rhythm, with ticking drums and deft keyboard interjections.

label: Teen / Dub Store
review: A heavy, rumbunctious, rocking version by a young Monty Alexander, with a tasty eastern tang; plus a terrific rolling shuffle, on the flip.

label: All Stars / Dub Store
review: A teenaged Montgomery and friends from school, trying out Wild Bill Davis and stuff from the radio, with a JA twist.

release: My Forefathers Died In The Sand
label: Pressure Sounds
review:
Stunning, poignant Strange Things vocal excursion, with stripped nyabinghi version. 
No more captivity, free all humanity.

label: Carifta / Dub Store
review: A locomotive Ben E. King cover and some wistful Deadly Headley. Derrick’s singing is clear as a bell; Striker Lee is on the throttle. One to stick next to DM’s Seven Letters.

label: Digikiller
review:
Bringing together two sevens originally released in Jamaica on the Afro Black label, in the mid-seventies. Rootical domestics, soulfully delivered, over tight, funky playing. You Let Me Down is Wackies’ sublime Black Harmony rhythm, no less. 
Collectors’ heaven, utilising Joe ‘Basement Session’ Morgan’s own imprint Fish Tea, going since the 1980s.

label: Digikiller
review:
Throw down your tin-pan bootleg and come.
Heavyweight roots originally released in late-seventies NY on the singer’s own JoMor Music House label, under the name Billy Joe Morgan. Tough horns, with Joe deftly recycling Freddie McKay’s Rock A Bye Woman, in magnificent discomixes.
Watch out you don’t miss the killer digi excursion Warrior, from ten years later, storming up the rear.

label: Digikiller
review:
A fine mid-seventies excursion on the murderous Black Harmony rhythm.
‘Produced by Joe Morgan’, surprisingly enough. Turns out he produced this Soul Syndicate rhythm track back in 1975, together with vocals by Don Carlos et al, all mixed by Tubby’s. Moving to the Bronx soon afterwards with the tapes in his luggage, Joe decided on Wackies as the best outlet… As it was written, indeed.

label: Kentone / Dub Store
review: Burning sufferers ska to run alongside Vernon Allen’s Babylon. Too hot for the Jamaican Skarama LP (and unissued before now). Tell them, Monty.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Spine-tingling, yearning, rootical rocksteady classic — one of Phil Pratt’s top tunes - with an ace Tommy McCook version.

label: Digikiller
review: The Heptone on a rocking melodica version of Conquering Lion.

label: Digikiller
review: Irresistibly body-rocking, early-nineties digi — with vivid spaghetti detailing, as the unflappable Sixy keeps it holstered, and coolly rides west on a murderous b-line, rearin’ and careerin’ into the sunset.

label: Only Roots
review: His masterwork, from 1975. Great songs — a tough mix of mysticism, politics and philosophy — with Robbie Lyn from the Sound Dimension, Geoffrey Chung gently testing the reggae envelope, Clive Hunt from Wackies, a sprinkling of Black Ark, masterful drumming by Horsemouth… and PM’s compelling voice.

label: Tuff Scout
review: Wow… the triumphant comeback of the indomitable King Culture. Super-heavy, Radics-style, wrecking-ball rhythm; proper singing; tough dub. The mixing of the harmony singing is magical.

label: Rebirth
review:
‘Close your eyes. What do you hear? Do you hear your own heartbeat? Do you hear the grasshopper which is at your feet?’ ‘Old man, how is it that you hear these things?’ ‘Young man, how is it that you do not?’
Musical Kung Fu care of Clive Hunt at the Black Ark.

label: Rebirth
review: ‘Man must vank these money men / Who pay I and I to fight I bredrens / Just because I’m in hunger / Them hold I with them dunza / Penetrate man with them dunza… Oh, there shall be lightning and thunder / For the heathens who take advantage of sufferer / To gain their vanity of power / They shall reach their final hour / They will be cut off forever, yeah.’

label: Only Roots
review:
His second LP, for Island in 1980. 
Sophisticated Geoffrey Chung runnings — with Freddie McGregor, Judy Mowatt, Candy McKenzie and Rita Marley amongst the chorus, and Sly & Robbie, and members of Zap Pow, In Crowd, Light Of Saba, Wareika Hill Sounds…

label: Federal / Dub Store
review: Caribbean lounge-jazz from the veteran pianist, supported by the Ernest Ranglin Trio. Japanese import.

release: Starring Lee Perry As The Upsetter
label: Pressure Sounds
Hot Milk
review:
Renford Ferguson of King Stur-Gav Hi-Fi, aged nineteen, at Aquarius in 1983 for the Roots Rockers label. 
‘A remarkable retrieval job,’ writes Steve Barker in The Wire. ‘One of the deepest voice, drum and bass excursions… from darkly minimal early analogue JA dancehall to [amongst the CD additions] jump-up digi from the UK and a live Stur-Gav session from Negril Beach. With detailed, respectful sleevenotes, this is reggae revive up to the old gold standard of Blood And Fire.’

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Murder from the Africa Must Be Free LP, and version, beautifully done.

label: Message
review: Stunning thriller from the monumental Africa Must Be Free LP, never out on seven before, plus masterful dub. Such a great singer, shot dead at twenty-one during an argument about a stolen food-mixer.

release: Jah Says The Time Has Come
label: Message
review: “Africans a bear the most pressure, because you find that the people that are controlling them are the white people them. They try to be superior over black people. Not all of them, but certain of them ones as is gods and seat up in high places. All those system, you just see them big notches who a control. Certain of them captains and them big pirates from long time is them family. Some of them people really have the world in their hands, so them keep up various kinds of isms now. Them stop slaving the Africans alone, but them slaving everyone else still. Is the people to come and unite now, that’s the only way.” (Hugh Mundell talking to Black Echoes magazine in 1980.)

label: Roots Vibration
review: Soundboy anthem from a few years back, rinsed by sounds like Chalice and Aba Shanti.

label: Black Art
review: Next deadly vocal on the ineffable Police & Thieves rhythm: less philosophical; more pissed off, accusatory and retributive.

label: Firehouse / Dub Store
review:
The great singer addressing false authority, apartheid and the squandering of black lives. The rhythm is Tubby’s ace, ominous, digi re-working of Yabby You’s Conquering Lion. 
Dubplate business from Dub Store in Tokyo.

label: Sound Of World
review: Great to have them back — this was recorded in 2005 — though here they’re sometimes a little MOR.

label: Black Art
review:
Gorgeous, peak-period Black Ark music; lovely dub.
Also known as Forward With Love, by Mystic Eyes (on the Heart Of The Ark album), this is a reissue of the 7” on 56 Hope Road… always tough to find.
Les Clark — who sang Free Up Blackman for the Light Of Saba — with Anthony Johnson… and a nightclub chef from Mayfield Avenue, named Balvin Fials.

label: Shamala
review: Winston’s daughter, on a vintage Channel One rhythm; produced last year by Franklin ‘Steamers A Bubble’ Irving. Straight to the head of all nationalists and xenophobes.

label: Dug Out
review: Brilliant, icy, rude-boy minimalism, ticking and clopping out of the Vibes Sounds studio in Mayville Road, Leytonstone, East London, in 1987. Blacka at the controls, Jah Warrior the apprentice dentist.

release: Rockstone — Adventures with Lee Perry at the Black Ark
label: Pressure Sounds
review: One Wayne Jobson at the Ark — that late sound — also Channel One, and with Spear’s Black Disciples at Jack Ruby’s studio.

label: Digikiller
review: A heavyweight, bumptious Tempo excursion from these Jammys associates, with a haunting message, implacable drums and bass, and sick synths which unravel meltingly in the dub. Super-rare and killer.

label: Peckings
review: Stellar lineup, on a Prince Far-I.

label: Black Joy
review: Tough Jammys productions; quality German revive.

label: Reggae Archive
review:
Shaka fire fanned at Fashion, but originally released on Race Records in 1981 (with a hand from The Specials).
Plus two dubplate-style mixes; and a Manasseh excursion from 1989, with Danny Red.

label: Destroyer
review:
Jackie Mittoo and the makings of The Upsetters band — the Barrett brothers and Alva Lewis — shaking up Brentford Road in 1970, dead ringers for the Sound Dimension. The almighty Sir Niney cracks the ninetails. Dr. Cocaine brings up the rear.
ITS COMING ITS COMING, ITS A MUSICAL EXCITEMENT, PRIZES, SURPRIZES, THE GRAND…. MUSIC POLICE RAFFLE. 
Classic, legendary stuff — A MYSTERY AND A MUSICAL HISTORY, a baffling raffling — beautifully reissued by Rock A Shacka, of Osacka.

label: Hornin' Sounds
review:
Lovely, haunting, unique Ethiopian reggae, recorded in France in 1984. 
Chunky and rootical, not to say zonked, with sick synths, and sweetly doughty singing about respect for your parents and making Africa great. 
Beautifully presented; warmly recommended.

label: Dug Out
review: Another Black Victory classic missing in action, with superb rhythms and killer dubs, a dream combination of Studio One and Bullwackies musicians, and the young sing-jay already at the top of his game.

label: Vena / Dub Store
review: Tough early-eighties Fatis digi, over which our hero finds himself trying to get next to a gay woman who looks like a man. Even his Japanese shoes fail him.

label: Prince Jammy's Dub / Dub Store
review: Killer! Super-hard-bitten Jammys version of Tempo, from right at the back of the deep-freeze, with a brilliant dukes-up from Nitty Gritty. Soundboy see them a come. All three of these are by way of Dubstore in Tokyo — the Far East Ruler — and previously unreleased.

label: Jah Fingers
review: Fierily imperious roots from 1998, for Opera House. With Mikey General and a dub; and a show-stealing toast from label-boss Buccaneer.

label: Shebazz
review: Bovell’s hard-swinging, tumpin, parping do-over of Spear’s Resting Place, with a nice dub.

release: I A Tell... Dubwise And Otherwise
label: Iroko

artist: Once Upon A Time At King Tubby's
label: Pressure Sounds
review: An uproarious survey of the wittiest of all the wars-of-words in reggae. Cameos from Johnny Clarke, Jazzbo, Derrick Morgan — but I-Roy takes the honours (and pity anyone coming up against him).

release: Fabulous Songs Of Miss Sonia E Pottinger Vol 2
label: Drum And Bass
review: No let up by the Drum And Bass crew — just check the sound samples — more rock steady treasures unearthed.

release: We're Gonna Rock It Tonight (Dub Plate Playing)
label: King Jammy's Dub / Dub Store

release: In The Area (What A La La)
label: Jammy's / Dub Store
Techniques
review:
What a tune. Stone killer roots from 1981.
‘You’re going to church on Sunday. There’s no love in your heart on Monday…’
Dwight Pickney, Jackie Mittoo, Steely, Sly, Robbie, Roland Alphonso, Boris Gardiner, Chinna, Ranchie, Ansel Collins, Tommy McCook, Bobby Ellis, Drumbago… Soljie and Winston Riley at the controls.
Plus Jimmy Riley’s excursion; and both dubs.

label: Summer Records
review:
Recorded under the name Bumpy Jones, for Jerry Brown’s Summer label in Toronto (same Upsetters family tree as Bullwackies and Half Moon). 
Ramshackle, tottering, bloodshot; brilliant, freely creative and compelling.
The killer dub is entitled Jah Jah Symphony In B Minor. Pretty droll.

label: VP
review:
Originally out in 1981 on Jah Guidance, featuring heavyweight murder like Kiss Somebody, Back Off, and Nightfall itself. With the Roots Radics Band at Channel One; a couple of Papa Tullo toasts; mixed by Scientist; produced by Linval Thompson. 
The big deal here is that no less than five full disco mixes have been subbed for their original short-pants LP counterparts.

artist: Count Ossie And The Mystic Revelation Of Rastafari
label: New Dimension / Dub Store

artist: Count Ossie And The Mystic Revelation Of Rastafari
label: Soul Jazz

artist: Count Ossie And The Mystic Revelation Of Rastafari
label: Dub Store
Gay Feet / Dub Store
review:
Party music for sufferers, Count Ossie style: deep, spiritual and hurt, but still up for it.
Plus a sensational nyabinghi version of Miriam Makeba’s massive Pata Pata, with Patsy pon mic.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Massive, magnificent instrumental, sound-system murder since day one. The acoustic guitar is class.

label: Virgo Production
review:
The classic digital destroyer, recorded at Aquarius in 1987.
Cyaan be no loefah.

release: One Love, One Heart, One Family
label: Jah Solid Rock

release: Africa Must Be Free By 1983 Dub
label: Rockers International
Greensleeves
review: Excellent dub set originally released in 1988, based around Tetrack’s classic Let’s Get Started LP, from nearly a decade before. Roomy and reverberating, with synths preferred to melodica.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Instrumental piece of Willie Williams’ killer sufferers. The flipside dub is not on the compilation.

label: Get On Down
review: Cutting his teeth at Impact! with Clive Chin. The Heptones, Dee Brung, Swing Easy; an unforgettable lesson in dub (‘Leave mi studio, sah!’). Crucial crucial crucial crucial.

label: VP
review:
Stone classic rebel rock from the teen at Randy’s in 1973, riding the success of Java. The Barrett Brothers, Chinna, Zoot Simms and co on an Upsetters, Santics like Horace’s Problems, Guiding Star. Ever awesome.
The more expensive, LP is from Get On Down.

release: El Rockers Chapters I To IV
label: Greensleeves
review:
Four sticks of Real Rock: a deejay cut from Jah Iny, sick clavinet, signature melodica, and King Tubby at the controls. 
‘Real gone scorcher,’ as Iny would say.

label: Dug Out
review:
First time out for this wildly raw dubplate, sister-recording to the Pablo master-rhythm, shot through with other-worldly, illusively allusive incantation.
Surely that’s Family Man stalking a sunken cavern, and his bro battering all seven shades out of his drum-kit, like Meters on fire; and Chinna on guitar, glazed and violent. The mixing rears up right in your face. 
Producer Gussie Clarke says Theophilus ‘Easy Snappin’ Beckford is playing piano, with the front removed so he can strum the strings (like he finally snapped) — but he credits the work overall to Augustus Pablo. 
Transferred from acetate — fuss-pots don’t grumble, just be humble — though the flip brings a clutch of criss, unmissable alternates, direct from Gussie’s tape-room (where the files are entitled ‘Classical Illusion / The Sun’). 
Heavy, heavy funk. Simplicity People dug in. Stunning.

label: Hot Stuff
review: Interpretations of the Soul Vendors’ Swing Easy on melodica and clavinet; plus a dub, and a toast by Dillinger. Hot stuff is right.

label: Pin-Up
review: Slightly theatrical female sufferers from 1977, arranged by Cedric Brooks.

label: Greensleeves
review: From 1982 — with the Roots Radics and Jah Thomas at Channel One.

label: Greensleeves
review: With Jah Thomas and Toyan — and a Little John on the flip.

label: Digikiller
review: George Nicholson was a mainstay of Channel One at its height in the mid-80s, running his own Tasha imprint on the side. First of three excursions on the Strokes rhythm.

label: Digikiller
review: The grizzly-monster original 1984 cut (not the Power House do-over), plus shoot-out dub; with a Steve Knight excursion on the flip.

label: Early Days
review: Excellent digi from a brand new French label, with the champion juggler in full flight on the stones-glasshouse theme. ‘Stop tryin’ to be a tuff scout’... Camden posse, feel no way.

label: Tuff Scout
review: Great to have the Saxon man back, in top form on this slug of nasty NW1 digi.

label: Tuff Scout
review:
The great UK MC retrieves his war chest from the potting shed. 
An expert, moody Tuff Scout re-lick, with a haunting new vibes part and lethal effects.

label: Treasure Isle
review: The Treasure Isle masterwork… plus a sweetly rocking Tommy McCook.

label: Treasure Isle
review:
The almighty rocksteady classic.
Plus a lovely Tommy McCook version of The Shadow Of Your Smile, to run alongside Astrud Gilberto.

label: Digikiller
review: Tremendous though unreleased mid-tempo killers — yearning and moody, with the golden Radics touch; both songs with dubs.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: From 1980, re-kitted with bass drum and toms, for the dance.

label: Lee / Dub Store
review: Curtis Mayfield, every way but loose. A version of The Impressions’ classic marks PK’s first recording with Bunny Lee; and Glen Adams moodily rides the same rhythm Lee used for Slim Smith’s cover of Gypsy Woman, on the flip.

label: Digikiller
review: Created By The Father… Dennis Emmanuel Brown business.

label: Gay Feet / Dub Store
review: Tough, lovelorn rock steady, with tasty organ asides. The flip is a lovely revive of the signature tune of the great JA calypsonian Lord Flea, bossed here by Lennie Hibbert.

label: Pablo International
review: Strong, mystical song over a stone-classic Augustus Pablo dub of the same momentous rhythm as Hugh Mundell’s Revolution A Come. This issue’s heavy, concussive version sounds like dubplate pressure.

label: Digikiller
review: Great early-eighties Channel 1 excursion on the same version of DEB’s Revolution rhythm as Barrington Levy’s Black Rose.

label: Digikiller
review:
Militant mid-seventies roots with a strong Upsetters flavour, but produced by Benbow Creary. Originally out on Micron. 
Same singer as Life Is Sweet (Sweeter Than Money) on the rhythm aka Tippertone Rocking; and Don’t Give Up, with the Upsetter himself, a few years before.

label: Digikiller
review: Bim! Paula is yearningly soulful over a brooding rhythm by The Gladiators Band, classic Channel-One-style and brilliantly dubwise from the start — whilst Singie Singie is relaxed and engaging over another brilliant, quite different mix on the flip. Valiantly retrieved from releases on W&B in Toronto and Tonos in the UK. Both sides discomix.

label: Digikiller
review: Heartfelt, blessed early-eighties Maxfield Avenue roots, in short supply from the off. Pressed from the original stamper, Digikiller-style: a few clicks at the start can’t test rudie.

label: Merritone / Dub Store
review: Dapper 1967 rocksteady, previously unreleased. Eddie also recorded as a duo with Alton Ellis — Alton And Eddy.

release: Take These Chains From My Heart
label: Kentone / Dub Store

release: Roast Fish Collie Weed And Corn Bread
label: VP

release: Skanking With The Upsetter: Rare Dubs 1971-1974
label: Jamaican Recordings

release: Scratch And Company: The Upsetters Chapter 1
label: Clocktower
Tuff Scout
review:
Tuff Scout rises to the occasion with a majestic rhythm, echoing and musically boned, sat well back in the saddle like Brother Roy’s Different Experience; whilst the great man does an entertaining variation of Memphis Tennessee. Ace dub. 
Long Distance Information? May I speak to the High Priest?

label: Upsetter
review: Inimitably donning the Iron Shirt rhythm from War Ina Babylon. Straight to the head of all Prodigy fans.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Fret not, rudie — giddying, solid-gold killers abound in this haul of Upsetters dub-plates and alternate mixes. Pablo’s here, Junior Murvin, Bucky Skank, History Of Captivity, Billie Jean… Towering, sick genius.

release: The Return Of Sound System Scratch
label: Pressure Sounds
review: Actually, this time derived mostly from rare sevens, still not reissued, a handful of which makes this essential, like Jack Lord’s killer Economic Crisis; with extra dubplate pressure applied for good measure.

label: Honest Jon's Records
review: Originally released in 1980: the final work to emerge from the Black Ark studio, before its permanent destruction, crossing the soundworld of Roast Fish Collie Weed And Cornbread into new hybrids.

label: C And N
review: Silk-screened labels to die for. Killer Studio One ska originally out on C And N, Clement And Norma, Mr and Mrs Dodd.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Sixteen cuts of prime-period Black Art, all unreleased music or unreleased mixes (bar the Althea And Donna); mostly from master-tape, some dub-plates. Surely worth it just for The Fantels.

label: Trojan
review:
Utterly brilliant, pioneering dub from 1975, laden with genius, fresh air, good humour and strangeness. 
Woman’s Dub is astounding, still — a dub of Jimmy Riley doing Bobby Womack’s Woman’s Gotta Have It. ‘She’s gotta know she’s not walking on shaky ground,’ run the lyrics — amidst the awesome musical evocation of the far end of the Richter scale.
Hotly recommended at HJ for decades.

label: Wizzdom
review: Stupefying Upsetters genius — splicing together the rhythms of Better Days and Musical Transplant like Doctor Funkenstein himself, whilst Charlie Ace barks at Dinah the missus to get out of bed and pass him his trousers and an axe, there’s a cow-thief in the garden, needs his fingers chopped off.

label: Digikiller
review: Superb one-away roots production by Lloyd Barnes for the singer’s own imprint. No-prisoners organ; singing from the school of Pablo Moses.

label: VP
review: An excellent Echo Minott LP for Jammys in 1981. Sly and Robbie, Deadly Headley, Winston Wright and co. The opener is a killer next take of the awesome Open The Gate Bobby Boy rhythm.

label: Jammy's
review: From the Youth Man Vibrations LP, with a dub — worries and problem on the World A Music rhythm.

label: Rhythm Shack
review: Same vibes as Augustus Pablo at Impact. Tough and unexpected; apprentice melodica. With Teddy Irie ruling the B-side.

release: Dial M For Murder In Dub Style
label: Pressure Sounds
review: Fine late-70s dub LP recorded at Channel One: Sly and Robbie, Rad Brian on guitar, Bobby Kalphat and Ansell Collins keys, Tommy McCook and Herman Marquis horns. Phil Pratt and Errol T at the controls.

label: Pressure Sounds
review:
Moving vocal cut of his own Safe Travel rhythm, as featured on the flip.
Terrific stuff, though basking in the glory of The Heptones’ Crying Over You.

label: Digikiller
review:
Boof!
The grievously under-recorded AP’s searing rebuttal of domestic violence — longing and defiance shadowed by humiliation and desolation, over a deadly, sombre Channel One rhythm — backed with a tough roots excursion, fizzing with star-wars special effects, by Hands & Heart (who also recorded with Augustus Pablo and Lee Perry for Hungry Town, around the same time).
What a record.
Very strongly recommended.

label: Rock A Shacka
review:
The Buster selection we’ve been waiting for. 
A terrific haul of rare and unreleased sides; rocksteady gold, from start to finish.
Macka Osaka connoisseurship.

label: Tuff Scout
review: Tough Beres Simpson revive. With the Roots Radics, maybe.

label: Tuff Scout
review:
Heavy, early-eighties roots extracted from the Roots Me Roots LP. 
Tuff Scout in revival mode, coming clean with the dub.

label: Kingston Connexion
review:
Beris Simpson, from Glen Brown days, switching from toasting to singing for this majestic breakthrough, on a Sly & Robbie rhythm from Channel One. 
‘Nutten tried, nutten done… I said to Sly them, say, Well, wha’ appen, can I make a song, can I make a riddim?, y’know wha’ I mean? But I’ve got no money. Them say, ‘C’mon Prince, man, get on with it! Whe you waan do? All right, c’mon!’ And I just start singin’ the song, ‘cause I already had the song written, you see. And I start singin’ the song and they jus’ made the riddim then and there for me - for free, y’know, without a penny. I’ve never paid a penny for that song, and that song come to England and that was one of me biggest ever hit in England, and in Jamaica it was just one of the massive… when I come to England, people was pirating the song. You know?’ (reggae-vibes.com).

label: Prince Jammy's Dub / Dub Store
review: Tough Jammys do-over of Cuss Cuss, with dangerous bass and banging dub, and Junior in no mood for messing. ‘Galong before we chop off your hand.’

label: Greensleeves
review: Majestic 1982 LP with Junjo at Channel One.

label: Grade One
review: Massive MP tune… but check the flip for Wayne Jarrett reprising the Youth Man lyrics he cut for Glen Brown on the same Wicked Can’t Run Away rhythm, this time with youngster Shoamari. Bim! Original copies.

label: Burning Sounds
review:
Post-Yabby You, post-Gunman — superb recordings for Delroy Wright’s Live & Learn label, originally released as Jah Love in 1983.
Laid down at Channel One, with the Roots Radics and High Times bands, and The Tamlins on backing vocals; mixed by Scientist.
Try the clip of 2000 Years, to start…. Magnificent.

label: Freedom Sounds
review:
Killer next cut to Ethiopian Kings, with the late singer in full flight, laying into social injustice. Plus a tough Frankie Jones steppers on the flip. Both with dubs.
Bim.

release: Hold On To What You Got
label: VP
Maffi
review: The Stand High Patrol mic-man on a moody version of Mango’s Dollar Move rhythm. Japan-only, ostensibly, with printed insert and sticker, and an excellent, grooving remix by Tokyo-based Bim One.

label: Tuff Scout
review: Ace, Shaka-style steppers from the Rolling Lion studios.

label: Observer
review: Sly and Robbie holding down a magnificent, dubwise, widescreen excursion to Promised Land, steered by the all-time reggae genius of Niney the Observer, at the controls. Beautifully presented, too.

label: Crystal / Dub Store
review: Wicked little minor-key organ instrumental, with a killer intro and rare toasting by Ramon The Mexican — resident deejay of Harriott’s Musical Chariot Sound System — who later changed his name to Ambelique.

label: Tuff Scout
review: The one and only Truths And Rights versioned by Liverpudlian mic-man for Jah Youth (amongst others), alongside producer Gil Cang, veteran of Nick Manasseh’s Riz label. Both these are strongly recommended.

label: Tuff Scout
review: The return of Ramon Judah (from the first ever Tuff Scout).

label: Federal / Dub Store
review: Instrumentals in ska, mento and other Caribbean styles recorded in 1966, at the threshold of rocksteady. The only one of his eight Federal albums to feature ska. Super-fine LP from Dub Store.

label: Kentone / Dub Store
review: Fire! The Federal musical director walks it like he talks it. Blazing horns and jazzy brilliance all round.

label: Federal / Dub Store
review: The best of Ern’s sixties LPs. A lovely bunch of rocksteady instrumentals, suited and booted for reissue by Dub Store in Tokyo.

label: Dub Store
review: Brilliant jazz lyricism, in the style of Kenny Burrell, by the thirty-three-year-old, at an impromptu 1965 session in the Federal Studio, with pianist Leslie Butler, drummer Carl McLeod and bassist Stephen Lauz.

artist: Ernest Ranglin And Prince Buster's All Stars
label: Olive Blossom
Ranking Joe
review: With Dennis on the flip, Home Sweet Home.

release: Why Can't You Leave The Dread Locks Alone
label: Jah Fingers
Hornin' Sounds
review: Tough dubplate steppers from mid-seventies Birmingham, as rinsed by sounds like Siffa, Wassifa, Orthodox 38 and Nyah Esquire. All showcase style, extended with dubs; all previously unreleased. Lovely stuff, deftly retrieved by Hornin’.

label: Doctor Bird
review:
Unmissable ska shuffler by Buster’s favourite trumpeter, showing off his signature vibrato.
Properly pressed and presented; with money going to the Harper family, we’re told.
Murder.

label: Rawse
review: Jah Upton joins Lloyd Barnes and Prince Douglas at the desk for another must-have Bullwackies dub set, originally released in 1977. From tapes recorded at Tubby’s with the Soul Syndicate band.

label: Abba Jahnoi
review: Anthemic digi roots by the UK veteran, revived from a few years ago.

label: Digikiller
review: Heavy lovers, a Kush Dan I production.

label: King Jammy's Dub / Dub Store
review: Rock ‘n rolling Reid. With a Little John.

release: Rise In The Strength Of Jah
label: Rockers
review:
Norris’ killer first recording of his own song in 1981, before doing it over brilliantly with the Viceroys and the Radics, the next year. Not surprisingly Pablo brings extra sublimity and spaciousness — and superb backing vocals by Hugh Mundell and Delroy Williams.
Plus no less than Entrance Of Jah World on the flip, with its dread bass, hanging back in suspense and wonder.
Both with dubs. Handsomely sleeved.

label: Digikiller
review:
Tough, dubwise, early-eighties Roots Radics, expertly voiced by the Viceroy, on the rebound from Rockers International. 
Previously unreleased.

label: Merritone / Dub Store
review: Winston Matthews, Lloyd McDonald and George Haye — Wailing Souls to be. From 1966, this is classic vocal rocksteady, one of the certified gems in the Merritone catalogue. Backed with unreleased ska.

label: Merritone / Dub Store
review: The fledgling Wailing Souls, rocking steady but broken-hearted in 1966; backed with the perfect ska antidote, a previously-unreleased Hopeton Lewis pick-me-up.

label: Conqueror
review: Heavyweight dubs of DEB murder like Words Of The Father by Earl Cunningham, Warning by Desi Roots, Mop & Cry by Freddie McKay, Wood For My Fire by Black Uhuru, Slave Driver by Dennis Brown, Armed Robbery by Junior Delgado, Augustus Pablo doing over Swing Easy…

label: Digikiller
review: Classic! Evergreen Channel 1 rhythms dubbed to perfection. Re-cut straight from the original master tapes, in hand-silkscreened two-colour jackets, just like the JA original.

label: Digikiller
review: Top-notch 1976 dub LP from Channel One, extracted by Digikilller from the original tapes, and nattily sleeved. The set later voiced by the great I-Roy as Musical Shark Attack. Classic stuff.

release: Dub Off Her Blouse & Skirt Volume 3
label: Germain
review:
Classy Donovan Germain dubs from 1981, with rhythms from Channel One and Joe Gibbs, mixed by Scientist. 
Two years into the series and that geezer on the cover is still at it.

release: Dub Out Her Blouse & Skirt Volume 1
label: Germain
review: Donovan Germain’s first dub LP from 1979. Rhythms laid at Channel One with the Revolutionaries, and mixed at Joe Gibbs’ studio by Errol T and Errol Brown.

label: Digikiller
review:
With a silk-screened cover and poster!
From 1979, three years after the first volume — classic instrumentals from the interim, plus exclusive dubs to titanic Channel One like Alton Ellis’ Tell Me and the Enforcer’s Ride on Marcus. Sly Dunbar, Robbie Shakespeare, Ranchie McLean and Rad Bryan, augmented by a revolving cast of top hornsmen, keyboardists and percussionists.

label: Joint International
review: Wicked early-eighties Wackies, unsteady and moody, with a Hudson connection.

label: Burial Mix
review: Superb version excursion in the grand tradition of Tempo Explosion. Willie Williams kicks off imperiously, on a classic Rhythm & Sound rhythm (adroitly evoking Niney’s way with horns). Sugar and Tikkiman take a turn, besides Berlin faces like Cotton and Rod Of Iron. No one puts a foot wrong. Brilliant LP.

label: Burial Mix
review: Collecting the first five Burial Mix tens, all featuring Tikiman, with their dubs.

label: Burial Mix
review: The dubs of Burial Mix numbers 6 to 12.

label: Burial Mix
review: Burial Mix numbers 6 to 12: classic after classic, like King In My Empire, Queen In My Empire, We Been Troddin’...

label: Burial Mix
review: See Mi Yah remixes. Sweet Substance is Pete, one half of the Scion project (with Rene, aka Vainqueur).

label: Burial Mix
review: See Mi Yah remixes. A triumphant end to the series.

label: PK
review:
At their chilliest, most magnificent and dreadful.  
Brilliantly remastered, one-sided.

label: Rhythm & Sound
review: A brilliant, taut take on vintage Wackies, there on the flip.

label: Honest Jon's Records
review: ‘If you are poor, you walk in your shoes, you lean.’ Three Unity revive 12s in today, remastered and in spanking new sleeves. Altogether, as a label, the greatest UK digi there ever was.

label: Jah Fingers
review: Irresistible mid-eighties dancehall vibes from Music Mountain Studios.

label: Iroko
review: Winston Jarrett fronting a characteristically rugged, deep-funk Family Man rhythm.

label: High Music / Dub Store
review: Fine roots vocal over a moody, punchy rhythm. Likewise the flip — derived from the Well Pleased And Satisfied killer, Open The Gate Bobby Boy.

label: Digikiller
review: Classic early-80s Junjo-Radics-Scientist runnings, moody and heavy, with a previously unreleased dubplate mix.

release: If You Give To Me (Ruby And Diamond)
label: Digikiller
Wanted 45
review: Heavyweight Niney roots from the Archive corner.

release: Rockaway Meets Young Warrior Volume One
label: Jah Shaka
Rockers
review: Shame to miss Ricky Grant’s Free Basing… killer Pablo digi. Fine Tetrack, too; and Jah Bull on Pablo Armageddon.

label: Hungry Town
review: Slap-up retrospective of Everton Da Silva’s New York imprint, full of deadly co-presentations with Augustus Pablo’s Rockers, like The Immortals’ Can’t Keep A Good Man Down, Horace’s Problems…

label: Digikiller
review:
The cream of their three Bullwackies albums — murder like Revelation Time and Roll On — presented in lovely silk-screened sleeves. 
Six of the best by any test.

artist: Ronald Downer & Count Ossie, Lennie Hibbert
label: Gay Feet / Dub Store

artist: Ronald Downer & Count Ossie, Lennie Hibbert
label: Gay Feet / Dub Store
Digikiller
review: Same deadly rhythm as The Immortals’ Babylon. First time out.

label: Digikiller
review: Aka Peter and Carol, revising their classic Evil That You Do on the down low (with Peter trying out the lead).

label: Greensleeves
review: The vinyl debut of six inimitably brilliant Scientist mixes, appended many years ago to a CD reissue of Scientist Wins The World Cup.

release: Red Rose Will Make You Dance
label: Dub Store
Dug Out
review: A stinging, thumping, futuristic soundboy frightener, originally toted by JA producer Dennis ‘Star’ Hayles in 1989. ‘Tempo’ has mutated into shock treatment, controls set to vaporize all zinc pan.

release: Two Big Bull In A One Pen
label: Dub Store
Dug Out
review: Raw, stripped, auratic, Black Ark funk — the Final Weapon rhythm as Zen tutelage, no doubt inspired by Niney, with signature cowbell, scrubby guitar, bass bubbling in the pocket, The Upsetter mixing on the spot.

label: Digikiller
review: What a stunning turn-up! Never before released, here is the greatest producer in reggae at the very peak of his powers — sounds like 1977 — running the first, pre-Black Uhuru version of Love Crisis. That’s right.

release: Peace And Love In The Ghetto
label: Jammy's / Dub Store
review: Poignantly-reflective next version of Horace’s Jah Is The One rhythm (from the Pure Ranking set), with MR’s unmistakable moves, and dub.

label: Jammy's / Dub Store
review: First time out for this recent do-over of Yabby You’s mighty King Pharaoh’s Plague — with dub.

artist: RTKal, Fox, Shanique Marie, Equiknoxx & Swing Ting
label: Swing Ting
Action
review: Wholesome digi-roots bumper from 1990; rinsed by Shaka in the day.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: This rare roots outing by the lovers specialist is a sweet, heartfelt tribute to the great JA revolutionary. A Lloyd Parks production, with a proper dub.

label: Rockers International
review: Good advice, beautifully delivered by the pair who had appeared as pre-teens ten years earlier in the film Rockers. Later known as Bitter Roots.

label: Webb
review: One-away Channel One roots. Shaka vibes.

label: Digikiller
review: An unnerving ride on Yabby You’s almighty Conquering Lion rhythm — a darkly atmospheric tale of pestilence and the dark arts, our kind of Christmas Carol. Crowning a great year for Digikiller, this is essential.

label: Digikiller
review: Anguished, ill, millenialist setting of The Upsetter’s killer Fever rhythm. Perry has to take the credit, but this is another scorcher.

label: Black Art
review:
Magical, mystical, Upsetters roots.
A stunning alternate mix of Bird In Hand, from the Return Of The Super Ape album — together with its dub; and a one-away ‘Upsetting Rhythm 2’, in the fashion of the last Rockashacka Disco Bum. 
Bird In Hand is a version of Naushad Ali’s Hindi love song Milte Hi Ankhen Dil Hua Diana — ‘the moment our eyes met, hearts went bonkers’ — as featured in the 1950 film Babul. Check it here.
Bim! Another crucial bunny from Osaka.

label: Digikiller
review: Lovely female vocal version of The Gaylads’ classic, complete with birdsong.

label: Jah Tubbys
review: Outstanding Jah Tubbys, with an ace, militant dub. Ahoy A Mouse.

label: Crystal / Dub Store
review: Sweet early Lovers from the part-time Louis Armstrong impersonator also favoured by Lee Perry — backed with a fine, soulful, previously unreleased cut by Jackie Bernard’s Kingstonians.

label: Solomonic / Dub Store
review: Fine roots from 1986, with a dose of Burning Spear in the singing. Produced by the Blackheart Man, favoured by Shaka.

label: ON U Sound
review: Classics, rarities and unreleased tracks from the On-U Sound vaults. Quintessential, out-there Adrian Sherwood productions — saturated sheets of electronics, reverberating drum machines, ultra choppy tape edits — featuring three completely unreleased tracks, including a crucial early cut by Neneh Cherry, and six tracks never reissued on CD, amongst them the amazing debut recording of Shara Nelson, pre-Massive Attack.

label: Pressure Sounds
review:
Heavyweight, mind-bending dubs of early-80s Roy Cousins vocal productions.
Deadly.

label: Clocktower
review: Including a secret-weapon version of Baltimore.

label: DUB MIR
review:
Genius dubs of Barrington Levy’s Robin Hood set. 
By now aged 20, Scientist had got his break mixing the singer for Jah Life: ‘When I first met King Tubby I always been telling him that ‘I can mix, I can mix’. And he always telling me, ‘Well, kid, first of all you should be in school. You’re smoking too much weed. Several big men try to do this. You’re a kid. Nobody not gonna allow you to mix.’ I would keep on bugging him, bugging him, bugging him. But he always just had me doing TV repairs, fixing the amplifiers and stuff for him. One day when Jammy failed to come — like he always do most of the time — Tubby’s made me a bet. He said, I bet if I send you around there to work, you wouldn’t know the first thing to do. And he pretty much lost on his bet. The first record I mixed went number one.’

release: Introducing Scientist: The Best Dub Album In The World
label: Superior Viaduct
review: His first LP, from 1980 — Al Campbell productions recorded with Sly & Robbie at Channel One; mixed by the hubristic teenager at King Tubby’s. Terrific stuff… but a non-scientific title.

label: Jah Life
review: Ten killer dubs of Barrington Levy, mixed at Tubby’s, mostly unreleased — the album was shelved in late 1980 — resplendent in Oneil Nanco’s artwork.

release: Rids The World Of The Evil Curse Of The Vampires
label: DUB MIR
review: Evilous dubs of Johnny Osbourne, Michael Prophet (a deadly You Are A No Good), Wayne Jarrett… and three Wailing Souls — What A Feeling, Firehouse Rock and Bandits Taking Over.

label: DUB MIR
review: Ruthlessly brilliant dubs of classic Linval Thompson productions like Wayne Wade’s Poor And Humble and Johnny Osbourne’s Kiss Somebody. Courtesy of the Roots Radics at Channel One, by way of Tubby’s. De Materialize puts it perfectly.

label: Real Gone
review: With the Roots Radics, produced by Linval Thompson.

label: Tobin
review: Magnificent do-over of Dennis Brown’s classic Foot Of The Mountain. A TG Binns production from mid-seventies New York. Murder.

release: SKRSINTL Meets MX7 Inna Dancehall Showdown
label: ICS Library Records
review: Bold, exuberant, expansive re-charting of the same neck of the sleng-teng invasion as vintage Jahtari and Tapes. The Upsetter meets Raymond Scott meets Horsepower Productions… on a writhing, pinging bed of Spaghetti Western… at the synthy grassroots of Library. Next-level stuff from Seekers, after excellent releases for Bokeh and Boomarm. Tremendously enjoyable; warmly recommended.

label: Digikiller
review: Late-eighties Callo Collins production of the Youth Promotion cohort.

label: Fam's / Dub Store
review: Aka Olive Grant — the same Senya who broke through at Randys in 1974 with Oh Jah Come and Children Of The Ghetto — with The Wailers backing.

release: Everyday Is Just A Holiday (Alternate Take)
label: Treasure Isle
Kentone / Dub Store
review: This beautiful acoustic cut is previously unissued. Raw soulful lovers, with close-harmony backing, and double bass and guitar as irresistible as Egyptian Reggae. Terrific.

label: Edge / Dub Store
review: This classy lovers was Sharon’s breakthrough, fronting the Now Generation band for Geoffrey Chung in 1973, in an achingly regretful Armstead / Ashford / Simpson song about female disillusionment (laid waste by Cilla Black the previous year).

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Nice and knockabout… and a touch quaint. Unmistakably Upsetters.

label: Tuff Scout
review: Class-A, higher-region, mid-tempo roots, with fine dubs, excellent melodica.

label: Digikiller
review: Heavy, gorgeous, black harmony killer from Carlton Manning (the Abyssinians’ brother) for Cash And Carry, in the late-seventies, invoking Studio One days a decade earlier.

label: Jah Fingers
review: The Don in full flight over late-nineties Bunny Gemini. Plus a Yami Bolo, and both dubs.

label: Muzik City
review: Arguably the first, surely one of best of all Jamaican gun tunes, banned in 1966 by JA radio but picked up by Blackwell. Roy Richards wanders off into Three Blind Mice, halfway through.

label: Jah Fingers
review: Gospelised roots, produced by Delroy Collins in the late 1990s, with mixes by the Disciples.

label: Steeley & Clevie / Jah Fingers
review:
Triumphant do-over of the mighty Unchained rhythm from Bob Andy’s Song Book. 
The original 1994 7” was hard to find (and bootlegged in Japan).

label: Digikiller
review: Killer, stripped mix, with a slightly different vocal to the standard issue, bringing extra flashes of sublimity and raw menace; plus a dub beloved of Jahlovemuzik, back in the mid-1970s.

label: ON U Sound
review:
Second, 1982 album by the loose collective, featuring Prince Far I, Bim Sherman and Jah Woosh, and members of the Roots Radics, Slits and Glaxo Babies. ‘Heavy dread vibes, earthquaking dub and classic deejay chatter, recorded in the flash, heat and studio experimentation of post-punk London.’
With a 24” x 12” fold-out poster insert and digital download card.

label: Tribes Man
review: Including a killer mix of Homeward Bound, the Creation Steppers’ blazing update of The Skatalites’ Confucius; a heavy Spear; a heavier Fred Locks (with Reggae Reggae Sauce rocking the mic).

label: Digikiller
review: Terrific organ-and-bongo excursion on Touch My Soul, with more of a Studio One feel to the mix.

label: Iroko
review: Rootical sing-jay UK-lovers from the Dennis Bovell stable, with the man himself rocking the flip. Very nice.

label: E ERLM
review: The legendary Ras Muffet tuffet from 1979, on Rasheda’s own imprint, from tape — Shaka ju-ju, and cornerstone of the same lineage of Wolverhampton reggae as Actress’ Rainy Dub — twinned with a new Dubbing Sun mix.

release: Why Worry When I Can Pray
label: E ERLM
Rasheda Lioness
review: Mystical roots from the Shaka alumnus — with a hypnotic dub.

release: The Story Unfolds — The Best Of Sizzla
label: VP

release: The Journey: The Very Best Of Sizzla Kalonji
label: Greensleeves
Charm
review: Ranting and raving on rhythms courtesy of Fire Ball, Jazzwad, Steely And Clevie and co.

release: Top Sounds From Top Deck Volume 4
label: Top-Deck
Motion
review: Featuring some utterly stupendous space-funk (like Fugitive Dub) recorded at the Black Ark in 1975, and mixed by King Tubby. Tommy McCook on flute, Chinna on rhythm guitar, Lloyd Brevett on double bass, Lloyd Knibb on fire.

release: Independence Ska and the Far East Sound
label: Soul Jazz
Randy's
review: Backed with Charlie Organaire and the Randy’s All Stars — Royal Charlie.

label: Randy's
review:
Clear yellow vinyl — with the ineffable Lord Creator passing through…
‘I’ve travelled all around this world, to see what I can find, but all I’ve ever found… is no peace and a worried mind.’

label: King Edwards
review: With Raymond Harper, Baba Brooks, Drumbago and co.

label: Rebind / Dub Store
review:
Killer roots detournement of Georgia Turner‘s dread blues about a New Orleans brothel, to the tune of a seventeenth-century English folk song, by way of Bob Dylan, Nina Simone and The Animals.
Bunny Gale revives another folk song on the flip — Dead Man’s Chest — via The Viceroys’ classic Studio One outing.
More crucial Keith Hudson runnings, courtesy of Dub Store in Tokyo.

artist: Sky High And The Mau Mau
label: RAS
review: Yami, Garnett, Marcus Garvey words, Stalag in the mix. Well worth getting.

label: Digikiller
review: Two goes at this late-nineties digi homage to black leaders, originally released on Skyers’ own Family House imprint.

release: Present Taxi Gang In Discomix Style 1978-1987
label: Cree
Jackpot
review: Murderous next version of the almighty Horace Andy / Zion Gate rhythm, with Leroy Superstar Smart taking a turn in the witness box, alongside King Tubby… Nothing but the truth.

label: Fe Me Time
review: Great Jimmy Radway rhythm, brilliantly voiced.

label: Attack
review: Satta outing, with Trinity on the flip.

label: Digikiller
review: Storming seventies Channel One rhythm with the same kind of militant double-time drumming as Gregory’s Mr Know It All. Mr Smart sings his heart out. Like the I Roy, on seven here for the first time.

label: Digikiller
review: Leroy Smart on tough, mid-tempo Channel One is a hard act to follow… but female deejay Super Chick steals the show on the flip, smashing Fight Fight. Murder.

label: Jah Life
review: Super-heavy piece of Green Bay Killing, with an unreleased dub; and a Shaolin Temple excursion on the flip, with a tough Scientist.

label: Jackpot / Dub Store
review: What a tune. A surging, early-seventies Soul Syndicate rhythm, with a fulgent trombone solo; and succinct, profound reasoning from the Don, at his very best, about thinking for yourself. Rebel music to live by; as clear as a bell. That’s a tough Sleepy on the flip, too. Killer.

label: Life Music
review: Trump-card trumpet version of Joyride, aka Riding West.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Deeply soulful rock steady singing by the peerless Slim Smith, with an upbeat Webber Sisters on the flip. Bunny Lee productions, re-presented on heavy vinyl, in picture sleeves.

label: Chartbound
review: At Jammys in 1985, just prior to the Sleng Teng revolution. An excellent, old-school set, with plenty of strong, one-away rhythms.

label: Big M
review: The singing’s a bit dodge, but the sentiment is true, and the dub is tough, funky drum-and-bass business, with stiff shots of guitar and brass.

label: Pyramid / Dub Store
review:
Classy, proto-lovers, full-scale do-over of the Robert John 45 still big in Northern Soul circles.
The original arranger, none other than Gene Page gets a run for his money in the typically sophisticated instrumental version by Geoffrey Chung and the In Crowd.

release: Take Your Bible And Read It
label: Zion Disc / Dub Store

release: A Psalm Of Praises To The Most High 1967-1972
label: Dub Store
review: From 1967 Ras Michael occasionally sat in on recording sessions with Jackie Mittoo and the Soul Vendors at Studio One. Instead of getting paid for his work, he requested studio time for his own Zion Disc recordings as the Sons of Negus Churchical Host… ‘Reggae is a vision. Reggae is the word that hits at the heartstrings the mind can’t control. I and I get the message of Rastafari out through reggae. It is the black music line of message to the world. It is the black Rastaman line of message to the world. It is the metaphorical Black Star Line’ (Ras Michael).

label: Crystal / Dub Store
review: Brawny, get-onboard rocksteady, with nyabinghi drumming throughout — including a tasty break. A first sighting of Solomon, from Police And Thieves.

label: Gay Feet / Dub Store
review:
Hard to resist Junior Murvin in this teasing, saucy mood, on a lovely nyabinghi rocksteady rhythm.
With an alternate take.

label: Roots Man
review: Deejay cut, garrulous but who cares, with its own version.

label: Roots Man
review: Dreadnought roots, with a sweet vocal and rough dubbing, a bone to boot.

label: Studio One / Dub Store
review: Stupendous, previously unissued rocksteady version of the monumental Skatalites scorcher from a few years earlier.

label: Muzik City / Dub Store
review: Rollicking, mid-sixties, post-Skatalites ska thriller, led by Bobby Ellis and Roland Alphonso, with slightly different soloing to the original release. With the sweet, forsaken Summertairs: ‘I love you, Errol.’

label: Studio One / Dub Store
review: Stone cold murder. Archetypal, slow-mo, eastern-sounds post-ska from Jackie Mittoo, Dizzy Moore, Roland Alphonso and co, around 1965.

label: Coxsone / Dub Store
review: With a sweet Hamlins on the flip. From the compilation Studio One Schmaltz, out in time for Christmas. Superior Dub Store pressing.

label: Studio One / Dub Store
review: Scorcher. Ska at the threshold of rocksteady. Mittoo and Dizzy Moore do it to it.

release: Herman Chin Loy's Funky Jamaican Trip
label: Pressure Sounds
Studio One / Dub Store
review: A masterful, sublime cover of the Young Holt by the newly-formed combo; backed with Roy Richards’ classic harmonica version of Summertime.

label: Supreme
review: Unmissable next cut of Love Land, featuring an uncredited Delroy Wilson, dub-plate style. Plus a nuts Peenie Wallie from Mittoo and Dennis Alcapone. ‘News as it happens…. Three crows on the coffin.’ RIP Mr Brown.

label: Snapper
review: Jamaican mento and calypso by the likes of Tanamo, Count Lasher and Laurel Aitken; and the US rhythm and blues licensed there, in the run-up to ska.

label: Tuff Scout
review: Crucial Gil Cang re-do of the eighties classic, with the man himself at the mic.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Excellent, soulful, slowed-down interpretation of his own Studio One recording Contemplating In Your Mind. Phil Pratt at the controls this time.

label: Honest Jon's Records
review: From our heartlands — the late 70s Grove — a stupendous mixture of stomping disco, dub and steel band, in its lineage crossing Ginger Johnson (from London Is The Place For Me) with The Twentieth Century Steel Band.

label: Island
review: Landmark British reggae from 1978 — when SP supported the Wailers on the Kaya tour — out of the Handsworth district of Birmingham. Beloved by punks, and including Prodigal Son and of course — skewering the National Front — Ku Klux Klan, the album is filled with moody pointers to the 1981 riots. 180g, gatefold sleeve.

label: Sunshine / Dub Store
review:
Stupendous rendition of a Chinese folk song over red-hot rocksteady, produced by Ronnie Narsalla in 1967. Aimed at the Chinese community in Kingston; super-rare ever since.
The guaranteed musical detonation of any kind of dance or party.
Pure worries.

label: Digikiller
review: Group harmony niceness, originally the B-side of the NY issue of To Be Poor Is A Crime (the Shaka staple). Don’t miss the flip… an ace  Black Ark rhythm licensed in the day to Hit Run in the UK. Naff guitar, mind.

label: Digikiller
review:
Lovely 1970s vocal roots LP — featuring the sufferers’ anthem To Be Poor Is A Crime — prepared by Carl Fletcher for his Uprising label, but never released at the time. 
Beautifully presented by Digikiller, at last, with precious photos of the Twelve Tribes milieu.

label: Kentone / Dub Store
review: A tear-up duet, with The Skatalites on the boil; and some nice, searing JA soul from Dobby Dobson, with wailing organ and hefty backbeat.

label: Gay Feet / Dub Store
review: Stately ska loveliness, with Queen Patsy at her very best, showing her devotion to Frankie Lymon; and a previously unreleased Webber Sisters on the flip, fizzing with charm.

label: Kings Chambers
review: Wicked digi four-tracker by Samo DJ and Hidden Operator.

label: Soul Jazz
review: Ranging over time and styles, and never less than brilliant. Watch out for a young Prince Far I, Prince Francis doing his best Alcapone impression over Ethiopia, and Jazzbo on a discomix of Skylarking.

label: Soul Jazz
review: A different approach to the first volume. This is more like a selection of versions — all except the last three tracks here are the B-sides of sevens — and may be stronger for it.

release: Chapter 3: 18 Heavyweight Dub Cuts From Brentford Road
label: Soul Jazz
review: A representative sampling of the original Studio One dub LPs, plus a couple of wild cards. You can’t lose with the stuff they use.

label: Soul Jazz
review: Isaac Hayes, Booker T, Stevie Wonder and James Brown are in the house. Some of the unreleased cuts — the Jackie Mittoo spaghetti, The Sharks’ dread techno — are amazing.

label: Soul Jazz
review: Sugar showed Coxsone how to lick over classic rhythms to suit the changing times, layering on new bass, percussion and keys by the Underground Vegetables crew, behind sparkling new vocals.

release: The Sound Of Studio One In The 1970s
label: Soul Jazz
Soul Jazz
review: A blistering selection, with the series’ signature mixture of classic hits and recovered treasure.

label: Life Music
review: Tough, horny Jah Life rockers, perplexingly with the Mikey Jarrett / Channel One rhythm just recently revived by Digikiller, on the flip.

label: Digikiller
review: Three chilled, heavy dubplates deployed by Junjo’s Volcano and Hyman Wright’s Jah Life soundsystems, back in the day, on John Holt’s Chanting rhythm.

label: Jah Life
review: At Philip Smart’s HC&F Studios in New York, with New York’s finest… Jah Malla, Scientist, Leroy Smart and crew.

label: King Jammy's Dub / Dub Store
review: Stalag… and The Carpenters’ Top Of The World.

label: Prince Jammy's Dub / Dub Store
review:
A hollowed-out, minor-chord rhythm… SB bubbling moodily about ‘if you’re having a problem and you don’t know to solve them, down the road there is a party’... a stripped, brilliant dub.
Classic Jammys from 1987.

label: Tuff Scout
review: Mythical 1981 recording by the Mancunian eleven-piece, supervised by Prince Hammer. Reason was the sound-boy weapon. Compellingly off-kilter and atmospheric.

label: Merritone / Dub Store
review: Unmistakable themes from the TV series soundtrack, in party-rocking style, with biff-boof organ.

label: Taxi Productions
review: Monumental soul-reggae — maybe the definitive version of the Randy Newman song (though probably a Nina Simone cover) — in its full 12-inch glory, with a terrific old school rap from Welton Irie, and two dubs.

artist: Tapes Meets The Drums Of Wareika Hill Sounds
label: Honest Jon's Records
review: This started out a couple of years ago as a grounation drumming session above the old headquarters of the Mystic Revelation Of Rastafari, in Wareika Hill, Kingston, JA. Four funde, a repeta and a bass drum. Back in London, contributing flute and guitar, Kenrick Diggory unbottled the deep rootical psychedelia and sheer awe of Hunting — the Keith-Hudson-versus-Count-Ossie wonder of the world — and Tapes added electronics, a shot of Drum Song… and a giddily intense binghi dub.

label: Skateland Killer
review: Killer militant roots. Tarrus in full voice over a swirling, fired-up Frenchie do-over of the Roots Radics rhythm for Star, Daily News And Gleaner, by Eek A Mouse.

label: Merritone / Dub Store
review: The Tartans — Prince Lincoln, Cedric Myton, Devon Russell and Berg Lewis.

label: Merritone / Dub Store
review: Tasty rudeboy anthems from Cedric ‘Congos’ Myton, Devon Russell and co —  a dancehall tribute and a jailhouse portent. Double-bass in the place.

label: Merritone / Dub Store
review: Bumping rocksteady — with a gospel, Toots flavour to the A; a little more booting rhythm and blues to the flip.

release: No One Can Tell I About Jah
label: Cry Tuff
Kingston Connexion
review: Outstanding roots from 1979, produced by Prince Hammer. Tough dub. too.

label: Basic Replay
review: Six murderous outings for Lloyd Robinson’s immortal rhythm on this showcase EP collecting singles produced by King Culture in Toronto and Kingston, Jamaica, during 1980-81.

label: Amussu Music
review: Next cut of Spear’s Marcus Garvey rhythm.

release: The Sweet Sound Of Cocoa Tea
label: VP

release: My Whole Life Depends On You
label: Treasure Isle
review: Bumping, soulful ska. Plus Tommy McCook’s brilliant Goldfinger, on the flip.

label: Treasure Isle
review: Irresistible mix of sublime, Impressions-style harmony singing, punchy horns supervised by Tommy McCook, soulful existentialism and rocking steady rhythm; beautifully presented by Far East Records.

label: Dug Out
review: The key Black Victory album, produced by Bullwackies and Sugar Minott: a devastating, chilled, dread run of King Tubby’s Tempo rhythm. Surely the greatest one-rhythm LP of all time, with unforgettable versions of the Red Rose classic.

label: Basic Replay
review: Burial is chilled, laconic, killer. Commercial Bwoy cautions any rival selectors thinking of watering down their sets with r and b. Blacka, Keety and Tena at the Vibes studio, early 90s.

label: Dug Out
review: The up and coming Tenor Saw treated to full superstar treatment by a Studio One band, with a tremendous, chunky, runaway rhythm, dominated by Bagga’s roiling bass, burning horns and dubwise, lightning-clap percussion.

label: Treasure Isle
review: No less than an alternate take of the almighty rocksteady classic from 1968. Backed with a Tommy McCook instrumental featuring organist Winston Wright. Beautifully presented by Corner Stone in Japan.

label: Greensleeves
review:
Crucial. Ravishing vocal harmonies over magnificent Augustus Pablo rhythms. You can hear the Black Ark in the mix.
Only Jah Jah know but schoolfriends Carlton Hines, Paul Mangaroo and Dave Harvey professionally named themselves after their local soundsystem in Mountain View, which in turn copped the moniker from the Tetrarchic rule of the Roman Emperor Diocletian, in the third century.

label: Rockers
review: Sublime roots — with a Tubbys dub.

label: Radiation Roots
review: With Sly and Robbie, Soljie, Willie Lindo and co, after the move from Augustus Pablo’s Rockers set-up to Gussie Clarke’s Music Works in 1983. Extended disco-mixes.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Lovely group-harmony rocksteady from around 1968, produced by Derrick Morgan.

release: We've Got A Good Thing Going
label: Superstar / Dub Store
review: Young bros Glen, Dalton, Noel, Cleveland and Danny, irresistibly doing over MJ for Geoffrey Chung. ‘She makes my motor purr.’

label: Edge / Dub Store
review: Superb, soulful, easy-rocking, Philly-dilly reggae. Old-school call-and-answer vocals, full of personality and charm; beautifully arranged, with criss horns. Class.

label: Studio One
review:
First out in 1970, collecting a string of dancehall smashers and specials; all-time murder like Baby Why. 
Superb harmony singing by Keble Drummond, Elbert Stewart and Vince Stoddart, over prime Studio One rhythms by the Soul Vendors, including Mittoo and Sibbles… 
It’s a must.

label: King Jammy's Dub / Dub Store
review: Good grief, it’s actually The Chi-Lites, on a John John update of Sleng Teng.

label: Wackies
review:
Stone classic Bullwackies (as excursioned by Rhythm & Sound for Burial Mix), sensationally featuring two unreleased dubs, newly extracted from the master reels. Both are equally unmissable but quite different, with contrasting effects: the second dub adds ninety seconds, including whip-dem spring reverb. Drawn from the Selective Showcase LP, the vocal mix is more open and dubwise than the Sing & Shout LP offering, with less keyboards. 
Asked whether it should be mash or march, after some pondering Bullwackies replied: “That’s a good question.”

label: Wackies
review:
A fresh iteration of the mid-eighties LP (itself a compilation of recordings from the previous five years or so), replacing two tracks — Dancing In The Rain and All Things — with their full 12” versions. 
This is a deeply personable, expert, limber blend of roots and lovers, kicking off with an exclusive mix of the deadly Mash Down Babylon; dropping classic, lush, spaced-out Wackies dub science to close; and taking in reworkings of Lickshot, Billie Jean and The Righteous Flames’ I Was Born To Be Loved, along the route.
The moniker ‘Chosen Brothers’ is Lloyd Barnes’ spiritual way of sharing the credit for his solo projects. “Anyone in the studio at the time could be a Chosen Brother,” he says. In this case a full crew includes Sugar Minott and Prince Douglas at the desk; Jah Batta, Milton Henry, Wayne Jarrett and Junior Delahaye all on backing vocals; and such dream-team Bullwackies instrumentalists as Clive Hunt, Jerry Johnson, Fabian Cooke and Ras Menelik.

label: Pressure Sounds
review:
Nyabinghi soul. 
Beautiful, hymnal simplicity from Alton Ellis’ backing singers, historically led by Winston Jarrett, though probably fronted here by Danny Clarke. 
(As The Hurricanes, their You Can Run is another killer Lee Perry production.)

label: Gay Feet / Dub Store
review: Two goes, both brilliant, featuring ace trombone. The first take carries the swing, with its wailing, soul-jazz organ more to the fore.

label: Upsetter
review: Rude boy better check his pacemaker before the vocal starts. Shark-attack version of this monumental Upsetters classic. Alva ‘Slasher’ Lewis, the Barrett Bros, Winston Wright, Augustus Pablo.

label: Gay Feet / Dub Store
review:
Top-notch, super-soulful rocksteady.
With an alternate take.

label: Gay Feet
review: Jackie Bernard leading a thumping, yearning overture; backed with The Valentines’ classic Blam Blam Fever. Top-notch rock steady.

label: Earth Sound
review: Searingly soulful, bongoman rocksteady recorded at Federal for Sonia Pottinger in 1966 — a hotter-fire alternate take of Go Back Home. Leslie Butler at the piano kicks it off; Jackie Bernard from The Kingstonians wails the gospel truth, drenched in sufferation. Another stone-cold killer from the label. Don’t you murmur, Irma.

label: Gay Feet / Dub Store
review: Lloyd Charmers, Alva Lewis, Glen Adams and the Barrett brothers, holding a candle for ska at the close of the 1960s. With a precious, uptempo, alternate take, on the flip.

label: Shuttle
review: Billie Jean UK-dubwise. A police-shoot-out scenario, with gunshots, sirens and a daft vocal interjection — Book im, Danno — plus burning horns. Original copies.

label: Techniques
review:
Unmissable mid-seventies Viceroys, plus three deadly versions. Swingeing Niney-style rhythm; superb, swirling dub. King Tubby’s way with the vocal is unforgettable.
It’s a must.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Excellent vocal trio sides, produced by Phil Pratt — before the group reverted to its Viceroys moniker.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: The earlier Winston Riley cut of Nothing is so deadly — Tubby’s Coconut Oil dub, for crying out loud — it sets this googly up nicely, especially in the extended format. Less urgent; more expansive. Vocals plus dubs, both sides.

label: Waricka
review: Lovely, soulful, moody Sir Collins’ production, with the group edging from rocksteady into reggae. Lloyd Charmers vibes up the party, on the flip.

label: Giant
review: Exemplary rocksteady produced by Syd Bucknor in 1967, with backing credited to both the Soul Brothers and the Carib Beats, on different labels, back in the day.

label: Impact!
review: Strong sufferers by Sweeney Williams, with the Wailers Band.

label: BMN / Dub Store
review:
Beautiful mento sufferers for Ronnie Nasralla in 1966. ‘I am the man who fights for the right, not for the wrong.’ 
People say that’s the first deejay recording on the flip - the wonderful Lord Comic, and his cowboys. ‘Music is real sweet… For your dancing feet.’

label: Federal
review:
Unmissable Maytals, in previously unreleased recordings from 1965. 
Toots and co have this Coppa bang to rights — ‘Stop treating the people unkind’ — even before Don D boots him down the street and the hell out of Dodge.

label: Treasure Isle
review: Superb, previously unreleased ska group-vocal, with Baba Brooks and co in fine form.

label: Burning Sounds
review: A swathe of of the duo’s mid-seventies, old-school favourites, like Bit By Bit and their version of The Melodians’ Swing And Dine, corralled by BS in 1977 (by which time Blacka and Bingy Bunny were nine-to-five with Joe Gibbs and The Revolutionaries, and Bingy was planning the Roots Radics with new-Morwell Errol Holt).

label: Black Art
review: Magnicent thumping roots with some startling effects late on.

label: Carifta / Dub Store
review:
Ace organ-driven rocksteady cut of Love Is A Message, recorded at Treasure Isle on Bunny Lee’s ticket, by youngsters Jacob Miller, Lawrence Weir and Lassive Jones aka Delroy Melody. 
They were going by the name The Young Lads, but Jones remembers Striker’s strong advice: “there are too much Lads group, you boys are going to school, you boys are School Boys.”

label: Techniques / Dub Store
review:
The Shades had freshly peeled away from The Techniques, because besides singing Winston Riley wanted to try producing, and Bruce Ruffin needed room… and this is a gem of a calling card.
Sweetly hopeful, rocking rocksteady — with an undertow of foreboding — which Junior Delgado revisited for Dennis Brown, ten years later. 
There’s a killer Marry Me dub on Meditation Dub, judiciously beginning ‘Boss, boss, boss, boss, boss, boss, boss, boss, boss, boss…’

release: Black Ark Singles And Dub Plates 1972-1978
label: Pressure Sounds

release: Winston Riley's Rock Steady & Early Reggae 1968-1969
label: Dub Store
Pressure Sounds
review: Lovely, early-seventies, group-harmony reasoning, produced by Phil Pratt, following up Rebel Nyah.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Classic, trumpet-led, early-seventies Upsetters instrumental. Like The Ethiopians and the Jimmy London, with an exclusive version, not included on the forthcoming album. Criss labels.

release: The Good, The Bad And The Upsetters
label: Hot Milk
review: 1971 JA riposte to Trojan’s unauthorised 1970 LP. Same title; different tracks. Funky, scrubby instrumentals including a couple of Wailers, with some hot Val Bennett, plenty of tough organ and a tasty side portion of Carly Barrett.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Dubs of Keep On Moving, Rainbow Country and Police And Thieves.

label: Get On Down
review:
A set of early, pioneering  Upsetters dubs, originally released in 1973, the same year as Blackboard Jungle Dub.
Featuring Dillinger and Sir Lord Comic at the microphone; Family Man and Carlton Barrett, of course; and Augustus Pablo (on the almighty Words rhythm). The Stingers’ Give Me Power won’t lie down, with a full-length version as Double Power, and two further iterations stitched together with The Ethiopians and a dub of Junior Byles’ Fever, in Operation, to close.
Handsomely presented, too; faithfully minimal.

label: Antarctica Starts Here
review: A Trojan grab-bag from 1973 featuring I-Roy and U-Roy, and at least three ingots of sheer Upsetters genius: Kentucky Skank, his paean to KFC; In The Iaah, high as kites with the Wailers; and Jungle Lion, his seminal, rawly funky re-working of Al Green’s Love And Happiness.

label: Gay Feet / Dub Store
review: Agony aunts Clifford Morrison and Dada Smith from The Bassies, with George Blake replacing Leroy Fischer, in 1969. Cornerstone moonstompers, both sides.

label: Solomonic / Dub Store
review: Next Bunny Wailer installment from Dubstore Tokyo. You know the drill: silkscreened sleeves, beautiful labels, and out of this world selecting, like this limber, jazzy gem, still wiser than Solomon.

label: Solomonic / Dub Store
review: A gorgeous horns arrangement, with sublime close harmony singing, of their masterpiece of spiritualized socialism (by way of Curtis), with a typically fine Solomonic dub.

label: Solomonic / Dub Store
review:
Lovely, upful roots, with signature Bunny Wailer trimmings. 
The flip is a brilliant, dubwise, rare Big Youth, massive with life and creativity.

label: Coxsone / Dub Store
review: Lovely Impressions impressions on the eve of the group’s departure from Brentford Road.

label: Fam's / Dub Store
review: Re-launching the Mittoo classic, aimed one step beyond, with intrepid space synths and drum machine (and mangled chanting on the flip). Strong Upsetters flavours.

label: Coxsone / Dub Store
review: Characteristically daring report of Haile Selassie’s visit to JA, kicking off in Amharic. A knees-up crossing of gospel, ska and rhythm and blues — the pianist and drummer taking different views — with vocal backing by The Gaylads. Plus a Soul Brothers on the flip.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Sid Bucknor supervising a mix of master musicians from the London scene and JA visitors — Rico, Tan Tan, Lester Sterling, Winston Wright and co. Ace versions of Rebel Woman and the Lumumbo rhythm for starters.

label: Clocktower
review: His tough third LP, recorded with the Revolutionaries at Channel One, at the end of the 70s; mixed by Scientist at Tubbys and Douglas Levy at Bullwackies.

label: Jah Fingers
review: Outstanding, widescreen, blazing modern roots by way of the Dubmatix crew in Toronto. Horace Andy, too; and a shot of Wackies style and fashion in the mix.

label: Big Style / Dub Style
review: A deadly, zonked Soul Syndicate excursion on Westbound Train, with Keith Hudson as the Fat Controller. Introducing a young LT — his first recording, he says — stylistically indebted to Dennis Brown.

release: Give Me Back (What You Take From The Poor)
label: Iroko
Prince Jammy's Dub / Dub Store
review: Celebrated dubplate version of DEB’s Promised Land; and Earl 16 on Trial And Crosses.

label: Dug Out
review: Utterly inspired, gale-force ranting pon a flashin’ TR-909. The head-on, 1988 collision of harder-than-hard-core dancehall and ultra-raw Detroit techno. Soundboy will soil his winceyette onesie.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Bare, laidback Upsetters funk, deftly dubwise, with a young Junior Delgado at the microphone.

label: Sophisticated
review: Donovan Joseph leading this clattering, infectious 1994 do-over of the group’s late-eighties hit, calling all bus-drivers.

label: 5 Gate Temple
review: Rough, spangly dub stomper from one half of Shaka inner circle Earthquake Studio; with a John T Gast more leanly aghast pon flip.

label: Pressure Sounds
review:
A deeply satisfying set of meditational roots rockers, lit up by King Tubby. Unmissable for Lambs Bread Herb, a reworking of Yabby You’s Death Trap, with giddily mystical flute and overdubbed steppers drums. 
Says Bunny Lee — “When Tommy join up with Bobby Ellis on trumpet, that is when he develop what we call his ‘far east’ sound, especially when he play flute like on Death Trap. Or sometimes Tommy play clarinet for a different flavour. But mostly he play the tenor sax with that deeper, lower tone, like on Tommy’s Rocking Vibration – hear that big horn there!”

label: Merritone / Dub Store
review:
A fresh, deadly combination of rocksteady with funk and British Invasion. 
With a Beatles on the flip.

label: Isabel
review: Rock A Shacka / Drum & Bass runnings. Back in.

artist: Tony Benjamin And The I & I Band
label: Archive
Music Industry / Jah Fingers
review: 1983 excursion on an imperious Roots Radics rhythm. Proper soundboy roots from the Wailing Souls / Viceroys school of black harmony killers. Sexist crap, too.

label: Peckings
review: Paul Groucho Smykle revisits his eighties do-over of Don Drummond’s Last Call, as rinsed by Shaka on dubplate. Also featuring veteran deejay Ranking Joe.

label: Duke Reid
review: Sly, Robbie, Cedric Brooks, Winston Wright and co, mixed by Crucial Bunny.

label: Columbia
review: ‘What a big disgrace, the way you rob up the place… everything you can find, you even rob the blind. Now we know the truth… taking people’s business on your head, might as well you be dead.’

label: Solomonic / Dub Store
review: The Stepping Razor’s inspired melodica cut of Armagideon has the dreadest atmosphere of the lot.

label: Greensleeves
review: Classic LP with the Roots Radics, mixed by Scientist at Tubbys.

label: Wind / Dub Store
review:
Killer Osibisa do-over.
‘Trammy’ was the nickname of trombonist Ron Wilson; but this is Vin Gordon.

label: Black Roots
review: Soundsystem joints on the original Studio One Hot Milk. Bit ropey, but full of vibes.

label: Vena / Dub Store
review: Soulful steppers by TL, fresh from Tubby’s Firehouse.

label: Morwell Esq
review: Delroy’s bro in two feeling excursions on his punchy Better Must Come rhythm.

label: Iroko
review: Trinity’s best record, from 1978. On a steppers Love Without Feeling — dub-wise, clattering drums, blurting bass —  he chants himself into a lather about some bloke ‘calling people roach’. Errol Scorcher?

label: Hevyaka
review: Ace steppers, engineered by Munchie Jackson from Wackies, with militant horns and swirling female backing vocals, and a tough dub.

release: At The Grass Roots Of Dub
label: Greensleeves

release: Two Big Bull In A One Pen Dubwise
label: Dub Store
Greensleeves
review: King Tubby meets the Roots Radics.

label: VP
review: 1975 sequel to KT Meets The Upsetter At The Grass Roots Of Dub. Here’s Steve Barker in The Wire: ‘a chance to hear it as it should be heard, containing as it does a few moments of sheer Tubby magic, including Unit Dub, a pure and simple drum and bass outing with the bassline mixed up front and twisted through filters while a shrilly splitting hi-hat is left to steer the riddim. Definitely in the top ten of all Tubby dub mixes.’

release: King Tubbys Presents Sound Clash Dubplate Style
label: Dub Store

release: King Tubbys Presents Sound Clash Dubplate Style Part 2
label: Dub Store
Mango
review: Rough ‘n’ rugged roots killer from the Black Ark, engineered by Scientist and Pablo, with Sly, Horsemouth, Chinna, Family Man…

label: Redman International / Dub Store
review: Can’t bubble, can’t cook, can’t even dress properly.

label: Digikiller
review: The A was a Shaka dubplate special; the flip versions Truths And Rights, and was a Jahlove special. First time out for these monsters.

label: Vena / Dub Store
review: Soundboy vibes over a hard-driving, clattering rhythm.

label: Tuff Scout
review: Exclusive mixes of key versions in the TS mission so far, dub-plate style.

release: Trying To Conquer I / Don't Fight The Professor
label: Basic Replay
review: A mad beast of a Dave Kelly — as the label logo has it (derived from Tubby, like the music) — faced down brilliantly by singer and deejay. Out originally in 1989 — another death-in-the-arena BR revive.

label: Jammy's / Dub Store
review: Tough, thumping Jammys from 1989, with expert falsetto singing from CT.

release: At The Jamaica Hilton, In The Jippi-Jappa Lounge
label: Federal / Dub Store
review: Ah, yes… takes you back to 1968… and sultry Kingston nights loungin’ downtown with Madame Wasp (that’s her on the cover), to a chilled cocktail of rocksteady, calypso, pop, jazz, mood and bossa.

label: Get On Down
review: The monumental Treasure Isles. If only one deejay LP were chosen to outlast planet earth, this would have to be it, your ace from space, with version from creation.

release: Right Time Rockers: The Lost Channel One Album
label: Sound System
review: In full flight, over heavyweight Maxfield Avenue shots.

release: Foundation Skank: Rare Sides By The DJ Originator
label: Sound System
INBIDIMTS / Dub Store
review:
What a record. The studio debut of the mighty Daddy U-Roy in 1969, sparring with Val Bennett over Old Fashioned Way, both of them wigging out like a couple of beboppers, with the ghost of John Holt on the backing tape. “The studio is kinda cloudy,” reports U-Roy — and everyone sounds lit but utterly inspired. Pure vibes.
“My first tune I ever do was Dynamic Fashion Way with Keith Hudson, and then I do Earth’s Rightful Ruler for Scratch. Those tunes didn’t get very far, them sell a couple hundred.”
Cornerstone stuff. Show some respect and chuck your bootleg.

label: Wackies
