review: A 1977 dub album collecting  Wackies recordings made in JA — studios like Randys, Black Ark, Treasure Isle — and in NYC before the White Plains Road studio was established, where finally they were overdubbed and mixed.

label: Jamaican Recordings
review: Fierce Niney productions mixed by Tubby. Awesome stuff.

release: Sledgehammer Dub In The Street Of Jamaica
label: Burning Sounds
review:
Tough Niney rhythms — for the likes of Dennis Brown and The Heptones — laid down by Soul Syndicate, Philip Smart and Errol T, mixed by the King. (Castro Brown added a couple of Cimarrons dubs, courtesy of Syd Bucknor in Chalk Farm, when he let off a couple of hundred whites in 1977: the last two tracks here.) 
Santa Davis on drums — those flying hi-hats copped off Earl Young in Philadelphia — and  Tubbys at the controls… fire.

label: Burning Sounds
review: Tough dub counterpart to The Heptones’ Better Days set.

label: Lee / Dub Store
review: Unmissable rocksteady: a magnificent version of the Curtis; and a hard-rocking Never Let Me Go.

label: Blue Cat
review: Ace rocksteady — backed with Festival song La La Bam-Ba, as a male-female duet, recorded at Studio One.

label: Pressure Sounds
review:
Super-heavyweight Family Man, Billie Jean business.
The dub is exclusive to this essential seven-inch.

label: Light In The Attic
review: Look out for Wayne McGhie, Jackie Mittoo and Johnny Osbourne passing through from Studio One. Also Alton Ellis’ son, Noel, and numerous local one-aways. Lovingly researched.

label: Jah Fingers
review: Rumbling, bleeping digi steamrollers from Leicester’s finest.

label: Digikiller
review:
Gorgeous roots harmony reasoning over a spare, brooding dub, produced by Sly & Robbie at Channel One in the early 80s, and previously only released on dubplate. 
A must.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Tight horns re-cut of the Safe Travel rhythm. The bone asks the questions; the flute tells the tale. The DigVin artwork is a homage to Johnny Moore and Tommy McCook’s label JonTom.

label: Defenders / Dub Store
review:
Staggering, stone-classic roots, originally released on Family Man’s handsome imprint in 1972, now lovingly revived by Dub Store in Tokyo. 
Bunny Wailer on percussion; Dirty Harry on fife. Awesome Tubbys dub.
Stupendous record.

artist: Vivian Jackson & The Sons Of Jah
label: Micron
review:
Magnificent, militant roots.
Tell them, King Tubby.

label: Wackies
review: ‘From over 150 singles and 20 albums these 10 extracts are showing you the quality and range of Jah Reggae music’, as the cover puts it.

label: Wackies
review: The musicians are Itopia augmented by Leroy Sibbles and Jackie Mittoo. Also Annette Brissette on drums — her solo album provides three outstanding cuts here, featuring Menelik in fine style on percussion.

label: Wackies
review: From the original sleeve-note — ‘reggae music is reaching its peak and this album is a perfect example of the roots of its success… an exceptionally well put together album with various artists at their best.’

label: Wackies
review: Magnificent dub album out originally on the Senrab label in 1976, drawing on a series of brilliant sevens and twelves on labels like City Line and Wackies, and sister imprints like Upton, Versatile, and Munchie Jackson’s Earth label. Core rhythm tracks from Jamaica — Treasure Isle mostly, with Tubbys mixes — worked over at the Sounds Unlimited studio on E 24th Street in Manhattan, given the full treatment by  Lloyd Barnes alongside Prince Douglas and Jah Upton, in the first months of the White Plains Road headquarters.

label: Live And Learn
review: The Radics at Channel One; mixed at Tubby’s by Scientist. The title track is the business.

label: Solomonic / Dub Store
review: Magnificent, militant roots with the heart of a lion — BW’s greatest record under his own name, much superior to the version on the Liberation LP, this was originally released as a UK disco 45 in the early eighties. Beautifully presented by Dub Store in Tokyo, with excellent sound.

label: Solomonic / Dub Store
review: The finest of his dancehall interventions with the Roots Radics, as the eighties progressed. This is taut and simple, tough and atmospheric, triumphant.

label: Solomonic / Dub Store
review: Beautiful sufferers music, so fluent in feeling, concern and hurt — with an inspired Big Youth. Way deeper than the Blackheart Man version.

label: Solomonic / Dub Store
review: Heavyweight, apocalyptic Bunny, with a burial b-line, burning horns, masterful dub. By a mile the best thing on Blackheart Man — and in its full glory here, and beautifully presented by Dub Store in Tokyo.

label: Jah Music
review: The blank originally revived a few years back by PK (to the licensor’s utter bafflement), and released together with a new ‘version’ by Rhythm And Sound, entitled No Partial…

label: Greensleeves
review: The best recordings by our favourite vocal group in reggae, back around on vinyl.

label: Jammy's / Dub Store
review: Magnificent WS digi — hurting, wise, sad, gorgeous — with a one-away by Wacked on the flip, easily over-looked but excellent.

label: Jammy's / Dub Store
review: Love Punaany Bad — a tale of hard times in New York City, with a nice steelpan sample; and a badman Admiral Bailey.

label: South East Music
review: Steady yourself and run the dub.

label: Greensleeves
review: Ferociously magnificent, utterly crucial collection of his late-seventies singles, chanting it down like a more blood-and-fire, non-bucolic Burning Spear. The CD adds such unmissable Welton Irie toasts as Black Man Stand Up Pan Foot and Wicked Tumbling. Produced by Glen Brown, mixed by King Tubby. Towering roots reggae, inspired through and through, from start to finish; hotly recommended.

label: Bongoman
review: Horsemouth the herb vendor in a meditative mood — crossing Upsetters and Pablo vibes at Brentford Road, no less. Totally killer roots melodica one-away. Where Do We Come From? What Are We? Where Are We Going?

label: Honest Jon's Records
review: Two no-flim-flam, cross-border, dub-wise stompers — paired with masterful versions — from the veteran, Kingston-based unit led by the trombonist of Count Ossie’s Mystic Revelation Of Rastafari and The Light Of Saba.

label: Honest Jon's Records
review: From this veteran of the Count Ossie group and The Light Of Saba — ‘These are my recordings from the last couple of years, blazing grounation roots reggae.’

label: Honest Jon's Records
review: Full, bone-heavy horns, swirling organ and rocking nyabinghi drumming; and with a storming dub.

label: Honest Jon's Records
review: An exclusive mix, featuring the original Light Of Saba drummers; with two new instrumentals, one in a more laid-back grounation style, the other blood-and-fire; and a chant, upful and defiant.

label: Honest Jon's Records
review: An unexpectedly upful, shuffling, percussive rug-cutter, with the Light Of Saba veteran bringing a little go-go to the grounation, and a deft, lovely dub mixed by Moritz von Oswald.

label: Honest Jon's Records
review: Headlong, fierce, banked rasta drumming fit to discombobulate any kind of system, with sweet, jazzy trombone riding it down, bubbling bass driving it home, and all of it classically dubwise.

label: Honest Jon's Records
review: Evoking his time with Count Ossie, four new grounation furies — hypnotic, thunderous, urgent, mystical — with dubwise repeta, funde and bass drums embedding the Light Of Saba man’s t-bone classicism.

label: VP
review: Some Joe Gibbs classics — Rockers Nu Crackers, for example — and more recent stuff with Lloyd Campbell.

release: Unity Sounds From The London Dancehall 1986 - 1989
label: Honest Jon's Records
review: Exhilarating reggae music from Stoke Newington, north east London, made by soundboys on a Casio and a drum machine, in a room over Eddie Regal’s record shop.

label: Upsettress
review: Rough, tough, searing steppers from the Meditation, with a killer-diller Dillinger, produced by  Isha Morrison — Mrs Lee Perry — and originally out on Orchid.

label: Burning Sounds
review:
The debut LP of David Jahson and Jerry Baxter, from 1978 (featuring the classic, parping Black On Black, from four years earlier).
The CD adds the Love Train album.

label: Total Sounds
review:
The definitive excursion on this almighty-killer rhythm — a favourite of Yabby You — in three, stunning, ferocious, Tubby-style mixes, maxed-out and dubwise from the off, with blazing horns, concussive drums, brilliantly intrepid xylophone, and lovely, militantly soulful singing and toasting.   
Resplendent in a printed sleeve, like the original (surely one of the greatest reggae 12” of all time); adding an extra dub.
Magnificent. Rougher than rough.

label: High Music / Dub Store
review:
Two cuts from the LP High Times Present New Talents Ghetto Youths Showdown.
The MW is killer roots, not to be missed. You can hear Scientist in the dubwise mix.
With Clive ‘From Creation’ Hylton, on the flip.

label: Digikiller
review: Sweet mellow roots from the man named after Kingston College, with some total classics under his belt from JA — No No No, Anywhere But Nowhere — before becoming a Wackies stalwart in NYC.

label: Digikiller
review:
Rough and tough Channel One, lifted from 1980’s Love People showcase LP, with an excellent dub. 
After the high-drama humiliation of No No No, it’s KC’s turn to dish it out, a little hard-hearted and indiscreet.

label: Basic Replay
review: Recording at King Jammy’s and Channel One in the late 80s, with Junior Delgado at the controls, Mice let off a series of records amongst the very deadliest of digital reggae.

label: Basic Replay
review: These are the blistering dubs to the companion album, many of them previously unreleased.

label: Archive
review: With the Soul Syndicate. Killer dub.

release: I Don't Want To Lose You
label: Pressure Sounds
Steeley & Clevie / Jah Fingers
review: A bit Whitey Mice, over a wicked mid-nineties Steely & Clevie.

label: Rockers International
review: To run alongside Tubby’s mix of No Entry.

label: Dug Out
review: Driving Shaka murder, fury and yearning mixed into a perfect marriage of digital and old-school music-making. Bagga Walker and a drum-machine tear up the dub. Complete with rare, ebullient Colarman toast.

label: Music House
review: The twelve-inch, with a different dub.

label: Digikiller
review: In fine voice on a punchy, dubwise rhythm — maybe the Gifted Roots Band — from the mid-eighties.

label: Jah Life
review: Start-to-finish killer combination of heavier-than-lead Roots Radics rhythms, wild Scientist mixing, and the Flick’s unique singing, often falsetto. Kicking off with an Ain’t Too Proud To Beg.

label: Digikiller
review: Moody, heavy lovers, detourned by FW’s full-throated falsetto. Ace.

label: Digikiller
review: The fine singer lighting up a vintage Junjo and Roots Radics cast-off. Originally released in 1984 on Kulumi, under the artist name Dandy Lion (with the same typo in the title).

label: Digikiller
review:
Marriage proposal on the same rugged Maxfield Avenue rhythm as Van Cliff, Patrick Cool and Nathan Skyers. 
Pull out the stopper, let’s have a whopper.

label: Digikiller
review: Heartically hymning male companionship over the same tough digi rhythm as Nathan Skyers’ Tribute To The Heroes… plus the dub. Previously unreleased.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Sturdy Marvin Gaye version. Produced by Phil Pratt and originally released on the Sun Shot label.

label: Clocktower
review:
Inimitably mixed by King Tubby; The Aggrovators on top form, likewise; rocking horns.
With an excellent Temps, and three lovely Chicago Soul covers. Nobody does reggae-soul better than Delroy.
Aka Sings For I & I.

label: Radiation Roots
review: Recorded at Chanel One in the early eighties, with Sly & Robbie and proper horns; produced showcase-style by Gussie Clarke, with dubs. The standout is a secret-weapon version of Is It Because I’m Black.

label: Digikiller
review: You can’t lose with Artibella, and this is a decent excursion by the great singer, with a lovely trombone-led version.

label: VP
review: Rugged 1974 dub LP replete with Upsetters and Tubby vibes, including the killer Macca Bee, and a nice vocal-with-deejay Love Me With All Your Heart, and featuring fine fleet flute froughout.

label: Taw
review:
A precious Upsetters gem from the Black Ark, circa 1976.
The story goes that only thirty copies were cut, in the day.
Reissued with letter-pressed sleeves and labels.
Hornin’ Sounds killing it three at a time.

label: Black Art
review: Lovely singing by the Hombres over a limber, spaced-out Upsetters rhythm you could listen to for hours. The dub attenuates the political reasoning with cruel brilliance.

label: Olive Blossom
review:
Bumptious, hurting rocksteady from the Be Prepared singer.
Characteristically, Buster sounds a lot less furtive and sorry than Percy Sledge, on the flip.

release: Deliver Me From My Enemies (Dub Plate Mix)
label: Pressure Sounds
Pressure Sounds
review: With the emphasis more on dubs and instrumentals, this round, but including unmissable interjections like Wayne Wade on Man Of The Living, and nuff Prophets. Tubbys such a massive presence ring-side.

label: Hot City
review: Sweet Vivian Jackson roots from 1976. Sunnier, more relaxed and intimate than usual; less of the lightning and thunder.

release: Chant Down Babylon Kingdom (Dub Plate Mix)
label: Pressure Sounds
review: Two dubplate mixes… but this is all about the magnificent Version.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Wonderful compilation originally released forty years ago by Grove Music — deftly interspersed with six additional selections.

label: Pressure Sounds
review: Roots gem from the Prophecy album, out of Channel One in 1981 — plus a previously unreleased mix. Trim printed sleeve, too.

artist: Yabby You & Michael Prophet Meet The Scientist
label: Dubmusic
review: Monster dubs of Yabby You productions of Michael Prophet, Patrick Andy, Alric Forbes and Wayne Wade, by way of King Tubbys. The first-round knockout is pure Shaka fire: an extended version of Gates Of Zion.

label: Pressure Sounds
review:
One half of this is the LP issued back in the day as Chant Down Babylon Kingdom, on the Nationwide label, split between Yabby You vocals and Tubbys dubs.
On the second platter Pressure Sounds unleashes a deadly tranche of previously unreleased mixes and outtakes, which shed ‘a revealing light on Yabby and Tubby’s working methods, and put the listener right next to the musicians in the studio. They frequently tried out different approaches on alternate takes, bouncing the 4 track tapes from one machine to another to free up tracks for overdubbing. Alongside chatter from the studio musicians, you can hear Yabby (in the vocal booth) communicating with Tubby (over his ‘talkback’ mic) as they shape the finished tracks. Yabby is constantly conferring with “‘bra (brother) Tubbs”, whilst Tubby keeps track of multiple takes of the same song. In the runup to ‘Love Of Jah’ you can really hear the two interacting, as Yabby asks “How that sound?” Tubby, typically understated, replies “Not bad.” Other highlights include “The Man Who Does The Work”, with Yabby singing a beautiful solo vocal with far less harmony accompaniment than on the released version, and an alternate cut of ‘Go To School Jah Jah Children’ with a flute and horn accompaniment (also used on the album’s dub version) and markedly different lyrics.’

label: Kingston Connexion
review:
Lee Perry’s awesome instrumental masterpiece.
With Carol Cole on the flip (who did Ethiopia, on Orchid).

label: Brownswood
review: Twin jazz-reggae interpretations of the immortal Augustus Pablo instrumental, with Zara following his melodica line; plus dubs.

label: Jammy's
review:
Majestic sufferers. Clear as a bell; implacable.
That’s Pablo in the mix, on melodica.

label: Carl's Records
review:
Outstanding set of dubs originally released in the late-1970s, out of Carl Campbell’s record shop on Church Avenue in Brooklyn, New York. 
Sly & Robbie, Augustus Pablo, Chinna, Tommy McCook and co; with Mikey Jarrett doing the ebullient intros. 
Dub For Joy is the standout, amongst several heavyweight killers.

label: Merritone / Dub Store
review:
A deadly rocksteady version of the ska tune they’d already cut for Duke Reid.
Dub Store business, from Tokyo, to their usual exquisite standards.

label: Jamaican Recordings
review: From 1979, with Tribute To Steve Biko.

label: Numero
review:
Lovely, rough, heartfelt doowop, with a dash of early Impressions. Prix demos.
As featured in the recent Ikea ad.

label: Soul Brother
review: Superb soulful Northern by Almeta Latimer Roseman, from Detroit. Produced by Leonard Jones in 1975; originally out on Mainstream. Pure class.Here she is singing back-up to Aretha in 1970.

label: Numero
review: Hurt, disillusioned, beautiful, pure, sensuous Windy City soul music from the mid-1970s, never out before — jazzy but street, musically sophisticated but emotionally direct.

label: Now Again
review: Underground soul and funk from early-seventies LA — Henry Porter, Jechonias Williams and co, with one foot inside the Watts 103rd St. Rhythm Band — lovingly unearthed by Now Again.

label: Sinking City
review: Bringing together two of the biggest Mardi Gras Indian crews — the 9th Ward Hunter Gang and the Black Eagles Gang. Heavy percussion and chanting. Fab.

label: Soul Power
review: Tough, fine funk instrumentals with an in-the-pocket Southern flavour, congas and horns, unison vocal chants. From Shreveport, Louisiana, 1973 — this is the Soul Power house band.

label: Aloha Got Soul
review:
The Japanese singer Aiko Sekiguchi teaming up with Dale Senaga in 1979. The pair flew from Hawaii to California to record the backing tracks at A&M Studios, returning with the reels to Commercial Recording Studio in Honolulu, where they added Aiko’s voice and Dale’s synthesizer overdubs (and Aiko resumed her residency at the Oasis nightclub).
Fly With Me is a sexy, exotic floater, crossing Love Unlimited-style two-step  and West Coast AOR. On the flip, Time Machine is jazzy disco steppers, with a cosmic fizz and a light case of the Gloria Gaynors.
More lovely stuff from Aloha Got Soul, moving achingly deep into Japan Blues territory.

release: Flat Out Funk From The Jazz Brotherhood
label: BGP

artist: Ain't Nothing But A House Party
release: The Birth Of The Philly Sound, 1967-71
label: Kent

artist: Alabama Christian Movement For Human Rights Choir
release: Do You Hear What I Hear?
label: TCF
NIA
review: The Leroy Burgess boogie classic, reprising Get Loose.

label: Heavenly Star
review: Stone-classic boogie-down from 1979, with CA fronting Gary Davis’ band of teenagers from Camden NJ. Peter Brown business.

label: Cherry Red
review: Jazz, rock, funk from 1970, with plenty of good stuff, featuring diggers’ totem and b-boy staple Cross Country (as sampled by Akinyele and Common, amongst others).

label: Warners
review:
The business… in a deadly shade of the Love Unlimited Orchestra. 
‘Over and over, time and time again. You can’t be nobody’s lover. You can’t be nobody’s lover… till you’re somebody’s friend.’

release: Let Me Say Dis About Dat
label: Aloha Got Soul
Aloha Got Soul
review:
Superb late-seventies soul from Hawaii.
Sleekly bumptious, with brilliant musicianship and classy arrangements, dosed with jazz and funk (by way of Kool And The Gang), easily traversing ballads and booty-shakers… just the kind of thing Wayne Henderson was doing across the Pacific with At Home productions, for Side Effect, The McCrarys and co.
Great stuff.

label: Polydor
review: From 1981, after his African tour, and LP collaboration with Fela. Classy, laid-back and groovy, with highlights including the title track’s svelte version of Afro-funk, and a new interpretation of The Third Eye. Sylvia Striplin and bassist William Allen — long-time mainstay of Mongo Santamaria’s band — both feature strongly.

label: Ace
review: For Your Precious Love started out as a Bandera recording (subsequently leased to Vee-Jay), made by co-owner Vi Muszynski — and there are eleven Impressions sides here, seven of them previously unissued.

release: Open The Door To Your Heart
label: Revilot
review:
Sometimes considered the greatest soul recording ever made, this was in the news a few years ago because a copy of the UK release on London Records went for £14,543. 
Sensationally, the flip delivers the previously unreleased instrumental version by the Funk Brothers — the Solid Hitbound in-house band including Rudy Robinson, Uriel Jones, Eddie Willis, Bob Babbit and Dennis Coffey.

release: Pushin' A Good Thing Too Far
label: Atlantic

release: The Life And Music Of New Orleans Piano Legend James Booker
label: Cadiz Music
review:
Unmissable film! 
A rawly soulful, moving tribute to the out-of-this-world artistry of James Carroll Booker, with dazzling clips of him in performance, various compelling interviews with his inner circle — where celebration and awe are cut with bitter frustration — and beautifully judged footage of the New Orleans locale.
In his autobiography, Queen Of The Junkers Joo Joo, Booker wrote: ‘It never occurred to me, until the age of four or five, that I was not a female, plus equipped to talk. The first woman I wanted to marry without doing it against my will was actually Tallulah Bankhead and another chick was a dude who identified herself as the Toast, the muffin or the Footloose Fancy Fruitcake among other commodities. Since then I heard she has not yet entered the Unorthodox Book of the almost Living.’ 
Booker liked dressing up as a woman called Juanita; he got nicked for impersonating plod. He did a stretch in Angola State Penitentiary, for drugs. He told people that Ringo Starr put his eye out, in a fight. He was way larger than life; just like his stunning piano-playing never shuts down into either ragtime or jazz, blues or classical (especially Chopin), and his singing is free as a bird.
Booker was born in 1939, around the time Jelly Roll Morton died (as he liked to note). Aged fourteen, his first recording under his own name was Doing The Hambone, for Dave Bartholomew. That’s really him playing piano on a bunch of Fats Domino and Little Richard records. He accompanied everyone from Bobby Bland, to Ray Charles, to Aretha. Amongst scores of 45s, his 1960 organ instrumental Gonzo — named after a mythical smack addict — was Hunter Thompson’s theme-song, and a smash for Peacock. Dr. John called Booker ‘the best black, gay, one-eyed junkie piano genius New Orleans has ever produced’ (which is faint praise).     
Big Easy portions of staggering, utter musical genius, sexual transgressiveness, drugs and booze, suffering, waste and mania. 
James Booker… such a don.
Watch it!

release: I Want To Hold Your Hand
label: Capitol

release: Try To Leave Me If You Can
label: Contempo

release: Now That I'm Gone (When Are You Leaving)
label: Gregar

release: The Lost Queen Of New Orleans Soul
label: Soul Jazz
Ace
review: Hats off every time to the founding father of New Orleans rhythm and blues. DB holds the master recipe for soul-ska-rhumba-blues gumbo. Just check the tracklisting for a sense of his achievement. Don.

label: Scepter
review:
Surprisingly satisfying soul LP from 1964.
No wonder Large Professor whipped Put Yourself In My Place. It’s killer.

label: Polydor
review:
Honky Tonk Popcorn!
Killer diller, undercover JB funk, featuring Bootsy and his evilous bro Catfish.

label: BGP
review: Late-sixties funk transformation of his 1956 smash, this time with the JBs. The flip is tougher yet, coiled and stinging. Both sides are sizzling killers; unmissable James Brown.

release: Over The Mountain, Across The Sea
label: Swan

release: You Were Born To Be Loved
label: Old Town

release: The Music De Wolfe Studio Sampler Volume 2
label: De Wolfe Music Library
Matsuli
review:
Insurgently crossing Philly Soul, Cape Jazz and bump jive in 1976, the same year as the Soweto Uprising; poignantly shot through with Timmy Thomas’ Why Can’t We Live Together.
‘It was so important for us to play a kind of crossover then, to weave in touches of Motown, Philadelphia soul and Teddy Pendergrass that the coloured community appreciated, and Basil’s Cape Town sound, and Sipho’s sound that was legendary in the black community, and make music that people could all enjoy together… The regime divided us: people classified coloured had identity documents; black people had the dompas. We didn’t accept that separation. Sipho, although he was born in KZN, could play any feel. Sometime he’d joke, Does my bass line feel coloured enough?’
Another landmark Matsuli. The title track is killer.

label: BGP
review: Blaxploitation soundtrack from the team behind Fritz The Cat, with Betty Everett, Walter Hawkins and Sonny Stitt, and some tough organ funk led by Merl Saunders.

release: Baby, Won't You Change Your Mind
label: Today Records
Now Again
review: Plenty of TKOs, the Colombians for example, beautifully presented. A moving, mind-boggling testament to Afrobeat, with shout-outs from Ghana, Trinidad, the US and elsewhere.

label: 4 Men With Beards
review: Detroit soul from 1973 — originally released on the Stax subsidiary Enterprise — cutting the funk-rock sensibilities of Funkadelic with vocalist Audrey Matthews’ ballads.

label: Be With Records
review:
Terrific, mid-nineties, Manc jigga jigga. 
Instant-classic UK street-soul.

release: Every Time We Say Goodbye (I Cry A Little)
label: Towne House
Numero
review: Best of the in-house Soul Kitchen, Luau, and Bounty labels: a treasure trove of kitchen-sink eccentric soul, fuzzbox funk, shoestring doo-wop, and haunted, eerily hook-laden spirituals. Out-of-this-world packaging.

release: Stretchin' Out In Bootsy's Rubber Band
label: Warners
Asterisk
review: Spiritual jazz and funky soul grooves from Chicago — The Temptations meet The Pharoahs, say — dug up by the Numero offshoot.

release: Funk, Fast Times And Nigerian Boogie Badness,1979-1983
label: Comb And Razor Sound
review: Music from the Second Republic, twenty-three years of military dictatorship ended, at the crest of Nigeria’s oil boom. Good-times disco-soul shuffle, mixing in jazz-funk, synth pop and Afro vibes.

label: Arista
review: The one with Say You Love Me Girl.

label: Athens Of The North
review: Vocalist Diane Broomfield and her five brothers in 1979, cresting a bunch of quality rare groove singles (and regular studio work at TK). As championed by Keb Darge.

label: Numero
review: Thrilling, superfly Chicago soul, from the Brotherman soundtrack also reissued by Numero.

label: Numero
review: Great mid-seventies Chicago soul, the real deal. (The film never materialised.)

release: It's A New Day — Let A Man Come In
label: Polydor

release: Tell Me What You're Gonna Do
label: King

release: I Can't Stand Myself When You Touch Me
label: King

release: Say It Loud I'm Black And I'm Proud
label: King
King
review: Warehouse find. Original, unplayed copies, with a small drill-hole through the label.

label: Polydor
review:
Generally derided forty-third LP, in between Reality and Hustle.
James is frank about his crown slipping — pretenders can’t even say ‘Good God’ properly, he rues on here — but once it gets going give us Dead On It over a bumperlicious bagful of trending Disco Classics, any day. Chicken Scratch Nolen, Sweet Charles and Maceo… killing it hard in their sleep.

release: Everybody's Doin' The Hustle & Dead On The Double Bump
label: Polydor
review:
Laying back a little in 1975, giving some to Leon Pendarvis’ clavinet and the female chorus (and saying goodbye to Fred Wesley). 
James is now re-anointed ‘Minister Of New New Super Heavy Funk’; and the ace do-over of Papa’s Got A Brand New Bag is a shot across the bows of the likes of P-Funk, the Ohio Players and the Love Unlimited organization. 
Hold on for the seven-minute version of Lieber & Stoller’s Kansas City.

release: Say It Live And Loud - Live In Dallas
label: Universal
Athens Of The North
review: Terrific, southern-fried-JBs runnings from Clarksville, Tennessee — low-slung, punchy, tell-it-like-it-is — fronted by bluesman Charles Suggs (with just three sevens to his name).

label: Now Again
review:
The fourth, 1975 LP of this Jazzman favourite from Houston, Texas, blending funk and spiritual jazz. 
With an extensive booklet, and a second disc of alternate, synthy versions of songs from Bubba’s first two LPs, besides some rare and unreleased disco and boogie.

label: Wildheart
review: Tripping, B-boy variations in two-step soul, with a tasty case of the gospel tremors. Vivid, layered, spaced-out — the aural equivalent of 3D glasses — and stuffed with fresh ideas.

label: BAU
review: With Londoner Emmavie, Angeleno Chris O’Bannon, and Buddy from the i Am Other crew; plus Queens rapper Meyhem Lauren, on the flip.

label: BAU
review:
Fatima on the ones; Joyce Wrice on the twos. 
Plus Musiq Soulchild via God’s own talkbox.

label: Holy Ghost Zone
review: Riding in resplendently on the cassock tails of The Gospel According To Budgie mixtapes and The Good Books (with Alchemist): still deeper, giddier blends of nineties gospel and 2018 bounce.

label: Numero
review: Invoking The Delfonics’ Do You Remember, and flipping its melody the other way around. Recorded at the Damon Studios in Kansas City (owned by Victor Damon, inventor of the spring reverb).

release: The Right Tracks: Complete Okeh Recordings, 1963-1966
label: Ace
review: Soul heaven, and magnificently comprehensive: the Northern anthem in amongst Chicago riches like top-notch Curtis songs you may not have heard and stone classics getting their first run out. Jerry’s younger bro.

release: Funk & Soul From The Golden State 1967-1976
label: BGP
Favorite
review: Three classy gospel-disco bubblers extracted from the Angeleno’s Intimate Friends LP, self-released on CBR in 1983.

label: BGP
review: Soul scorchers from Louisiana. A brilliantly convincing cover of Howard Tate, about relationship mindgames, hazily riven with sexual desire; and hard, driven funk on the flip, about men treating women badly. The red-hot band is Buckwheat and his Hitchhikers, before he turned to zydeco — recorded cyclophonically, according to the original label.

label: Honest Jon's Records
review:
Camille Doughty from Columbus, Ohio, in full flight over a gritty, funk-rock version of the gospel evergreen most famously recorded by Mahalia Jackson twenty years earlier; with some hard-grooving, Sam Cooke-style testifying on the flip, from The Singing Sons of Washington, D.C.
Beautifully sleeved; in limited numbers.

label: BGP
review:
The stunning, mid-seventies song behind Praise You, by this Chicagoan singer and activist, extending the traditions of Nina Simone, Roberta Flack and Gil Scott-Heron to more contemporary voices like Lauryn Hill, Erykah Badu and Frank Ocean. Check the album, too — The Iron Pot Cooker.
Backed with Jean-Jacques Perrey’s massive b-boy moog funk tune EVA, used by Gangstarr for Just To Get A Rep.

label: RCA
review: Her only solo release, in 1981, supervised by the Mtume crew: ace funky disco, indebted to Chic, and a very classy mid-tempo cover of Grey & Hanks.

artist: Carl Davis And The Chi Sound Orchestra
label: Chi Sound

release: I'll Give My Heart To You
label: Superfly
review: A quality mixture of P-Funk inflected underground boogie (like the opener), ballads and outstanding modern soul like Come Groove With Me and Since I Met You. Recorded in Knoxville in 1980, with one foot in the seventies, and combining southern and big-city soul idioms. Customary de luxe presentation by Superfly, Japanese-style.

release: Don't Let It Go To Your Head
label: Philadelphia International

release: You Got My Mind Messed Up
label: Goldwax
Kalita
review:
Outsider disco from 1977 — emotionally naked, electronic, no-budget — with the ineffable, unmissable Love Will Set You Free.
Here’s someone dancing to it on Clifton Bridge in Bristol.  
Like lovers rock pitched up somewhere between the Wigan Casino and Kling Klang in Dusseldorf.

release: I Forgot To Remember To Forget
label: Sun
Shadybrook
review: Satisfying mid-seventies blend of jazz and funk, soul and Latin, by this eight-piece led by singer and composer Cheyenne Fowler, under the supervision of Gene Russell.

label: Rhino
review: The LP was mastered at half-speed (under the supervision of Nile Rodgers) and pressed on 180-gram vinyl.

release: Carl Davis Presents 28 Classics From The Golden Age Of Soul
label: Grapevine
RCA
review:
Stone classic Allen Toussaint and Marshall Sehorn production. 
Killer funk like the rare groove protest of the opener, running straight into Time Machine… phew.

label: Honest Jon's Records
review:
Utterly magnificent, sublimely soulful survey of the Gospel Roots label, subsidiary of the mighty TK Records at the height of the Miami Sound.
A&R was co-ordinated by Gospel legends Ira Tucker — from the Dixie Hummingbirds — and Ralph Bass, veteran producer with Savoy, King and Chess. The label was run by Timmy Thomas, who had recently smashed with Why Can’t We Live Together, for another TK spin-off, Glades. Operations were overseen by Henry Stone himself, unlikely King of Disco, who had recorded a young Ray Charles, and pushed forward James Brown. They drew in artists from all over the US, from St. Louis, Columbus, Memphis, Brooklyn, Cabrini Green in Chicago: unknowns like Camille Doughty, reluctant to jeopardise her job at GM (‘Generous Motors’) in Detroit, and huge-sellers like the revered Brooklyn All Stars, who started out on Peacock in 1958. 
Choral belters, deep ballads, harmony quartets, epic city-blues, gritty funk, powerhouse female soul… Killer-diller Philly like a scorching version of Harold Melvin & The Blue Notes’ Wake Up Everybody; and Jean Austin’s raw Spirit Free, co-written by Ronnie Dyson, produced by Jesse James at Future Gold. Chicago Sound like The Fantastic Family Aires — named after the family’s furniture store on North Cicero, but reminiscent of the Staple Singers at their best — through to the full-blown glory of The Fountain Of Life Joy Choir, led by Marvin Yancy from The Independents, and featuring Natalie Cole… Singers like Versie Mae Gibson, from the Jordans, by rights up there with Irma, Etta and Ree… Bangers 100%-guaranteed to find their way into Theo Parrish sets; and mortal delirium for the prissiest of soul and gospel purists.
Beautifully presented… the LPs with a 12”-square, full-colour, sixteen-page album of photos and original artwork, the CD with a forty-page booklet — and truly outstanding notes, including insightful new interviews across the board; mastered at Abbey Road.
Dread and civitas, for Christmas; grit and transcendence.

release: Standing In The Need Of Love
label: PYE International

release: You Always Hurt The One You Love
label: PYE International
BGP
review: NYC soul, with at least two killers — Don’t You Care, and Never Did I Stop Loving You. BGP has unearthed some rarities; and some great photos.

label: Atlantic
review: Heavy jazz-funk — exemplary breaks’n'beats, sampled by Massive Attack on Safe From Harm — taken from the drummer’s 1973 album Spectrum. BC was on the rebound from the Mahavishnu Orchestra, along with keyboardist Jan Hammer. That’s Tommy Bolin from Deep Purple on guitar.

label: Expansion
review:
A gorgeous, heart-lifting, modern soul classic by this Santana alumnus, covering Johnny Bristol, from the 1976 LP Comin’ At Ya. 
Vocals by Errol Knowles (with the Waters Sisters), and none other than Joe Henderson on saxophone. That’s Linda Tillery singing on the flip.

release: Check Me Out If You Don't Know Me By Now
label: People

release: Black America Sings Lennon And McCartney
label: Ace
Columbia
review: What a great record. Soaring early-eighties soul from Bill Withers’ spar — original, loose-limbed and funky, full of emotional intelligence and good vibes. Includes Love’s Too Hot To Hide, two-step heaven.

label: Atlantic
review: Japanese issues of these stone classic Atlantics, with superior audio.

label: Sussex
review: Their best album, with a killer version of Bill Withers’ Who Is He.

label: Peoples Potential Unlimited
review: Scrappy, squawking, machine-funk stomper from New Orleans, originally spat out by Skye in 1982.

label: Favorite
review:
Mid-eighties, discofied, funkdafied zouk by Franck Donatien’s eight-piece combo from the French West Indies. A GD Production, by George Debs.
Santo Domingo is the stand-out.

label: Numero
review: Calypso, blues, disco, funk, reggae, bruckdown, soul, folk — in the kitchen, Belizians would call it Boil Up. For the New York Post, ‘indispensable’; the Chicago Tribune’s ‘best reissue of the year’ (2006).

label: Numero
review: Seventies Caribbean soul and funk — one ear tuned in to nearby Miami, with reggae and jazz in the mix too — from Frank Penn’s Freeport operation.

label: Numero
review: Almost preposterous, this beautiful snapshot of a US expat community fetched up in Dimona, Israel, in the second half of the seventies, holding faith with its love of Chicago soul and spiritual jazz.

label: Janus Records
review: The South Londoners’ amazing 1972 LP debut, including Caribbean-funk classics Bra and The Message, the deep Santana vibes of Dove, the playful grounation of Folk Song…

release: Live At The Jazz Cafe, London: The Complete Show
label: Virgin
RCA
review: Brand-new, pedigree r&b. Perforce nostalgic — heavy on the Paisley, dense like P-Funk, ecstatic like MPG — but a warmly recommended return.

release: You Can't Hide (Your Love From Me)
label: Mango
review: Body-rocking Larry Levan wickedness (soon after Joseph split from Hi-Tension).

release: Turn Back The Hands Of Time
label: Dakar
Light In The Attic
review: Her stupendous masterwork — the last word in raunchy hard funk, with Anti Love Song, of course, and three decent bonus tracks. Props to Sly Stone’s drummer Greg Errico, and Larry Graham. BD, so BaaaaD.

label: Light In The Attic
review:
Miles Davis and Teo Macero productions, with Hugh Masekela, John McLaughlin, Herbie Hancock, Wayne Shorter, Larry Young and co.
According to LITA, ‘the vibe is intrinsically unique, fresh, and futuristic — jazz heavyweights playing psychedelia, rock, and jazz-fusion long before the term became commonplace.  The songs include Betty originals and covers of classics by Creedence and Cream. The concepts explored on these previously unheard sessions fueled concepts that wouldn’t be fully realized until years later with Miles’ seminal On The Corner.’
All tracks bar two are previously unreleased. New interviews and rare photos.

label: Motown
review:
The title track was a smirking electro-funk smash for the Ohioans in 1983.
The two-step massive went for the much-less-cocksure Laughin’ At You.

release: There Ain't Nothin' I Wouldn't Do For You
label: Cameo

release: Take One: The Origin Of Twelve 70s Soul Masterpieces
label: Kent

release: La La Means I Love You
label: Philly Groove Records

release: Tell Me This Is A Dream
label: Philly Groove Records
Philly Groove Records
review:
Essential, exemplary Philly soul. 
Ready Or Not Here I Come is still giddily brilliant, undiminished by its recycling. 
Goin’ Out Of My Head is here…

release: La La Means I Love You, Sound Of Sexy Soul
label: Kent

release: Trapped By A Thing Called Love
label: Westbound

release: Funk And Soul From Dave Hamilton 1968-1979
label: BGP

release: Thirty Rare Gems From The Vaults Of La Beat Records
label: Grapevine

release: 2: A Further Fine Selection Of Independent Disco, Modern Soul And Boogie 1976-19
label: Soul Jazz

release: Scepter Records And The Birth Of Disco
label: BGP
review: Some great Tom Moulton here. The Patti Jos are essential.

release: Leftfield Disco Classics From The New York Underground
label: Strut
Numero
review: A fascinating delve into the bizarre and brilliant world of Jeremiah Yisrael and the funky disco  treasures of Tap Records. The boxed vinyl is beautifully done even by Numero standards, with 11 extras and a free CD.

label: Tidal Waves
review: The first and and only album by this Memphis musician — spar of Junie Morrison and Fuzzy Haskins — originally released in 1973 on Eastbound. Thirteen no-nonsense get-down psychedelic funk instrumentals, including two Funkadelic covers. Bad.

label: Numero
review: Two sides of standard-bearing, early-eighties Chicago disco by Donnell ‘Love Explosion’ Pitman, rescued from oblivion by Numero during a chance rummage through the briefcase of his ex-manager.

release: Kenny Dope And The Undercover Brother Present Dopebrother Studio A
label: Dopebrother
Charly
review: ‘The Greatest Hits And More, 1960-1978’ — with early obscurities, live stuff, ads and demos. The hits themselves are sublime New Orleans genius.

label: Backbeats
review: Pretty much all his essential Amy sides.

label: Numero
review: A Bahamian booty-shaker, heavy on the hand percussion, and some tasty, early-seventies funk.

release: A Legend In Her Own Time
label: Kent
Columbia
review: The resplendent classic rinsed by the likes of DJ Harvey — coupled with some deadly-gorgeous two-step. That’s Marcus Miller popping brilliantly on bass… Frank Wess from Trane days… the great Harold Vick.

label: Warners
review:
Their 1971 LP debut.
Bad Tune is… a bad tune. An all-time scorcher, push comes to shove.

label: Numero
review: Reviewing Ellis Taylor’s Kansas City imprint — from prime Marva Whitney all the way through to Sharon Revoal’s ace, slinky, early-eighties disco-funk.

label: Numero
review: Wonderful survey of the one-aways and lost gems of classic Chicago soul, named after Bob Abrahamian’s long-running WHPK radio show in the city.

label: Numero
review: Out of Phoenix, Arizona, Lenaburg’s 60s and 70s productions typify the wrong-side-of-the-desert sound (if ever there was). A melange of Tejano psych, flutey funk, horny soul, and fistfight doo-wop.

label: Numero
review: For twenty years in Detroit, this label failed at everything except what counts: soulful doo-wop, blistering garage funk, sultry R and B, cut-rate Hendrix over a steel drum break.

label: Numero
review: Four years of singles on the Lloyd and Deep City labels run by Willie Clark and Johnny Pearsall: sixties Miami’s rarest of the rare, including the vinyl debuts of Betty Wright and Paul Kelly.

label: Numero
review: The history of the Chicago label, and the life of its owner Arrow Brown: twenty tracks of blistering R and B, sweet soul, and discofied funk. Now on vinyl, in a sumptuous Numero box-set.

label: Numero
review: Short for ‘Capital City Soul’, this Columbus, Ohio label ran for five years during the 1970s. Founded by Bill Moss, a local singer and DJ, Capsoul released just a dozen 45s and one LP.

label: Numero
review: Even after various surveys over the years, a fresh, unmissable selection from this great Chicago soul label, with unreleased tracks. With 13 extras, the vinyl is beautifully packaged.

label: Numero
review: Fifty recordings on Jesse Jones’ twin labels out of Atlanta, between 1968-1977. Southern to northern soul, classic R and B to modern, dancers to romancers.

label: Numero
review: Drawing on Dick Smart’s group of soul labels run out of Wichita, Kansas, from 1963-75 — like Solo, Kanwic, Vantage and Lee-Mac.

label: Numero
review: Some gorgeous, classic, unmistakably Chicagoan soul here — the productions of Richard Pegue.

label: Numero
review: Quality sweet soul, ballads, thumping dancers, girl-group and the rest from Abe Epstein’s San Antonio label, late-1960s. Curtis and co in the air. Fine singing, big drums, strong horns, sophisticated arranging.

label: Numero
review: ‘The twentieth volume of our flagship series has all the boxes checked: gun-toting record producers, child stars, rip-offs, ‘The World’s Greatest Bail Bondsman’, soaring falsettos, and a dwindling rust-belt cityscape offering mere glimpses of hope before the record industry escaped for the coasts. Helmed by the O’Jays Bobby Massey, Saru was a creative vortex pulling into Cleveland the best talent in Cuyahoga County — the Out of Sights, the Elements, Pandella Kelly, David Peoples, Sir Stanley, the Ponderosa Twins + 1, Ba-Roz, Bobby Dukes and — of course — The O’Jays.’

label: Cairo
review: ‘The first LP compilation of songs by the great Eddie and Ernie!  The duo produced tons of great singles throughout the 60s and early 70s. This LP features a couple of dance numbers, but mostly slow dramatic soul ballads reminiscent of the best moments of more well-known acts like Sam & Dave and Otis Redding.  Some pretty eerie soaring vocals and existential lyrics of the highest order.’

release: Baby I'm Wise - The Complete Ric Singles 1959-1962
label: Ace
review: Classic New Orleans rhythm and blues, same cloth as Lee Dorsey and Ernie K Doe, before funk got a hold.

label: Tamla
review: With the magnificent proto-disco of Girl You Need A Change Of Mind, and the stunning, militant title track, this is the Temptation’s second solo LP, from 1972, and his best. It’s a must. Eddie ‘Bongo’ Brown, take a bow.

label: Deep Soul
review:
Five minutes of scorching deep soul. Knockout.
With Debbie Taylor singing a George Kerr on the flip… a few years before her all-time classic I Don’t Wanna Leave You.

label: Polydor
review: The tough, jazzy freedom song Wings Of A Horse was a Headz anthem in early-nineties London spots like Dingwalls and the Gardening Club.

label: Columbia
review:
Their third LP for Columbia — another Maurice White production, with stellar session musicians — including the two-step gems Walking The Line and Ain’t No Doubt About It. 
(The three sisters started out as The Hutchinson Sunbeams. The same year as this LP, it’s them on Boogie Wonderland.)

label: P & P Records
review: Super-rare, big-money, cream-of-the-crop Peter Brown productions — throwing down vintage electro, hiphop and funk. Supervised by the man himself.

label: Expansion
review: Deadly Roy Ayers productions, originally out on Uno Melodic in 1981. Both sides are two-step murder.

label: Peoples Potential Unlimited
review:
Slamming, synthy, late-80s funk somewhere between house, boogie and soul. 
As tightly leather-trousered, moustachioed and keen as Prince and Rick James.

release: I Want You To Be My Boy
label: Roulette
EYE
review:
The third Eye, as per — intrepid, ecstatic, off-grid wandering; one-sided, daubed discs resplendent in hand-painted sleeves.
Epic, this time… drenched, dazed, debauched… with Sly, Prince and Marvin amongst its guiding stars.
Refreshing; very limited.

label: EYE
review:
Fresh and new, but rough, layered and head-nodding like classic UK street soul, this is the fifth and for us the best-yet installment in Londoner EYE’s excellent, under-the-radar series. 
Slinkily slippery and hard-to-pin-down as usual, but rooted in funk and soul connoisseurship. 
Two-sided this time — boozier, dizzier and more spaced-out on the flip, smudged with echo and effects, and scraps of horns and singing. 
Beautifully hand-decorated sleeves as per.

release: Home Of The Muscle Shoals Sound
label: Kent
review: Otis, Aretha, Candi, Etta, Irma, Willie Hightower, Bettye Swann, Bobbie Gentry, etc etc etc… an 84-page booklet with numerous new interviews… plenty of obscurities and previously-unissued tracks… Essential!

label: Ace
review: The hits keep coming — just two of the twenty-six tracks here fell short of the US Top 30.

release: You Always Hurt The One You Love
label: London American

release: Ain't That Just Like A Woman
label: London American

release: The South Side Of Soul Street
label: Sundazed
review: Deep soul from the Minaret label, out of Florida, with an early Candi Staton, and the great Doris Allen.

release: The Untold History Of The Belgian Popcorn Scene
label: Jazzman

release: Do I Love You (Indeed I Do)
label: Soul Essentials
review: Legendary Northern — the last record played at the Wigan Casino — this archetypal heart-on-sleeve stomper was originally pressed in 1965 by Motown as a handful of promotional copies on its imprint SOUL. Most of these were destroyed soon afterwards, though people say Berry Gordy has a copy, and another was sold in 2009 for just over twenty-five grand.

release: Count To Ten: The Complete Singles Collection 1968-77
label: Play Back
review:
Sweet soul from Baltimore, produced by none other than George Kerr and Bunny Sigler.
The opener Count To Ten was their big hit, grabbing a couple of bars of Smokey Robinson; Candy is treasurably cannibalistic (‘her heart’s made of caramel’ etc); that’s a secret-weapon version of War (What Is It Good For?).

release: I Never Loved A Man The Way I Love You
label: Rhino
Atlantic
review: 1970 classic with five self-penned songs, and covers of Dr John, BB King, Jimmy Reed and Carole King. Backing by The Muscle Shoals Rhythm Section, Jim Dickinson, Duane Allman.

release: Rare And Unreleased Recordings From The Golden Reign Of The Queen Of Soul
label: Rhino

release: Just A Matter Of Time: Classic Columbia Recordings 1961-1966
label: Kent
review: Fab, zinging Aretha, pre-Atlantic, with the dodgy jazz and showtunes sifted out, and two recordings previously unreleased — the self-penned I Still Can’t Forget, and When They Ask, recorded when she was just 19.

release: Aretha with the Ray Bryant Combo
label: Speakers Corner
review: Her first album, for Columbia in 1961. Her voice is a total knockout already. Several killers here.

release: The Electrifying; The Tender, The Moving, The Swinging
label: Soul Jam

release: The Tender, The Moving, The Swinging
label: Waxtime
review: The third Columbia, from 1962, with almighty murder like Try A Little Tenderness and Without The One You Love. The Queen Of Soul, no contest at all.

release: The Gospel Soul Of Aretha Franklin
label: Rumble
Atlantic
review:
Both her utterly transcendent performances at the New Temple Missionary Baptist Church, Los Angeles, on January 13 and 14, 1972. Never on vinyl before (in their entirety). 180g, via Rhino.
The Queen at her most magnificent.

label: Soul Spectrum
review: Classic Miami soul, originally on Blue Candle, from this Jazzman imprint.

release: Way Down Yonder In New Orleans
label: Swan
Aloha Got Soul
review: New, twilit, woozily bumping electro-boogie from Honolulu — in a refreshing, in-ting break from the paradisal upfulness of Hawaiian soul — by the son of legendary Brazilian percussionist Carlinhos do Pandeiro, and Sandy Tsukiyama, collaborator of Nohelani Cypriano back in the day, and now a top radio deejay. Ace.

label: Prestige
review:
The 1971 debut LP of this old-school funky-organ soul-jazz combo from Indianapolis. You can’t miss the Jack McDuff in leader Bobby Watley. 
First up, their steaming version of a Kool & The Gang — quoting Mockingbird — has been sampled to hell: Jeru the Damaja, Jay-Z, Brand Nubian, Beatnuts, Schoolly D, Big Daddy Kane, the Beasties… Coming to Funk Inc. by way of stints with the likes of Etta James, Jerry Butler and James Brown, drummer Jimmy Munford should be a billionaire.
This top-quality reissue is by the Jazz Dispensary.

release: Acid Inc: The Best Of Funk Inc.
label: BGP

release: The Return of the Funk Soul Sisters
label: BGP

release: Standing On The Verge Of Getting It On
label: Westbound
Westbound
review: Moodymann, Underground Resistance, Marcellus Pittman, Shake Shakir, Claude Young…

label: Stones Throw
review: Assured, expansive, cliche-dodging new soul, with elements from the likes of Stevie, Todd Rundgren and Pharrell, and nice Latin percussion and strings throughout, via his French-Colombian family tree.

label: West End
review:
Monumental disco-boogie from 1981, in extended mixes by Larry Levan. Radically down-tempo and funky, with terrific, histrionic vocals. LL had to force-feed it to the Garage in the early days… though the Vinyl Mania shop round the corner went on to sell more than five thousand copies.
The original hot stepper.

release: Looking For You - The Complete United Artists & Veep Singles
label: Kent
review: Kicking off with his magnificent 1963 hit Cry Baby — both sides of all fourteen sevens. Superb sixties soul music, shaded out of doo wop, brimming with gospel.

label: Motown
review: Coming between What’s Going On and Let’s Get It On, this 1972 soundtrack is a bonafide masterpiece.

label: Tamla
review: The searingly soulful document of his divorce, and surely his greatest album.

label: Motown
review: Foundational second LP — with bvs by The Supremes, The Temptations and The Vandellas, songwriting help from Norman Whitfield and Barrett Strong, and The Funk Brothers laying it down.

release: How Sweet It Is To Be Loved By You
label: Motown

release: A Tribute To The Great Nat King Cole
label: Motown

release: I Want To Talk To You
label: Tec

release: It's Just The Way I Feel, Party In Me
label: Expansion
review: Neglected, laid-back, early-eighties soul, originally out on Capitol. The two out-and-out classics here both feature The Ridgeways on backing vocals: It’s Just The Way I Feel and Before You Break My Heart. Detroiter GD is the drummer on Roy Ayers’ Fever LP (alongside Bernard Purdie).

label: Suncut
review: Terrific, cut-loose, mid-seventies funk, with chicken-scratch guitar, rattling percussion and fatback bass, blaring horns and free-your-mind female vocals. Bim.

label: West End
review: Killer, low-slung, smooth-operator, electronic funk from 1982 — and impossible to find ever since — co-produced and mixed by Bert Reid from the Crown Heights Affair.

label: Epic
review:
Tom Moulton brilliantly extends this irresistible jazzy groover from 1979, featuring Lynn Davis’ superb singing, a fine keys solo, and a deadly, epic, signature-TM breakdown.
Plus the all-time jazz-funk touchstone Brazilian Love Affair, lit up by Airto on top form, the popping bass of Byron Miller, and dope Rhodes from George.
Class.

release: Temptation Is Hard To Fight / Every Time I Wake Up
label: Numero
Smallwood
review: GS on drums, bass, synth, rhythm ace and vocals, with Lady Disco herself singing back-up  (before going missing for the actual recording). Plus an alternate mix of Roller Coaster, recently remixed by Smallwood from the original studio masters.

artist: John Gibbs & The U.S. Steel Orchestra
label: EM
review:
The original 12” — released in 1977 on Gibbs’ own label — is a bonafide garage classic, rinsed by the likes of Larry Levan. Steel-pan disco bliss.
Here is the previously unissued long version which was the basis of the 1977 remix 12”. It’s around a minute longer and the mix itself is very different.

release: The Last Word On The First Blues
label: Omnivore
review:
The classic session plus eleven previously unissued performances, featuring contributions from Bob Dylan, Happy Traum, Don Cherry, Peter Orlovsky, Arthur Russell and co, in a luxuriously turned out 28-page colour booklet with rare photos and new essay by the producer Pat Thomas.
John Hammond was chuffed by the original release of The First Blues in 1983: ‘I recorded Allen in 1976 but Columbia Records refused to issue the results, considering the songs obscene and disrespectful. I am thrilled to finally be able to present Allen… I will present ‘disrespectful’ music like this as often as possible.’

release: Love Is Always on Your Mind
label: Buddah
review:
Crucial, deliriously magnificent disco, rinsed nowadays by the likes of Theo Parrish and DJ Harvey. Gotta be producer and writer Jerry Peter’s crowning ten minutes — notwithstanding his credits with everyone from Foster Sylvers and Gene Harris to Aretha and Marvin.
Plus no less than Bourgie Bourgie on the flip.

release: It's A Better Than Good Time
label: Buddah
review:
Seven minutes of fully-blown, ecstatic, boogie-down, Walter Gibbons genius. 
Apparently he used to deejay with a fourteen-minute dubplate. This version here was originally released only in Canada.

label: Ace
review: Stompers, floaters and ballads, with several impossible to get otherwise.

label: Numero
review: Primitive choirs, spacious breaks, congas, old-boy rappers impersonating the devil, cast-recordings, thumping bass, and JB copyists — all with a heavy slathering of gospel gravy.

label: Numero
review: A triumphant sequel to the Gospel Funk Hymnal.

label: BDG
review: Invigorating, intrepid mixtape-overview of a neglected period in gospel music, flowing irresistibly through sweet two-step, hard funk, disco stompers, jazz fusion, soul ballads etc.

release: The Best Of The Fame Gang
label: BGP
review: Funk scorchers from the house band at FAME in 1969. Freeman Brown, Jesse Boyce, Clayton Ivey, Junior Lowe… Knockout sevens like Grits And Gravy and Turn My Chicken Loose — equal parts Meters, MGs, JBs — with a heap of top-notch stuff out here for the first time.

release: Sounds Of Memphis Boogie, Soul And Funk 1975-1985
label: BGP

release: Rare And Unissued Gems From The FAME Vaults
label: Kent

release: Volume 2: More Unissued Gems From The FAME Vaults
label: Kent

release: Volume 3: More Rare And Unissued Gems From The FAME Vaults
label: Kent
review: Geezers, this time, no groups or female singers. Old friends reinforced by series debuts from the likes of Herman Moore, Dan Brantley, Roy Lee Johnson and Anon, sticking close to the golden years, 1966-8.

label: Columbia
review:
This is the sublime, eleven-minute killer, featuring vocalist Gavin Christopher. A big Theo Parrish record.
Backed with the promo-only disco mix of Saturday Night, lavished with percussion by Sheila E.
Murders.

release: You Can't Keep A Good Man Down
label: Polydor

release: You Can't Keep A Good Man Down
label: Soul Brother
review: All good, but including two or three sides of the greatest JB music there is.

label: Prestige
review:
The superb bebop pianist versioning the Jackson 5 — from his Greasy Kid Stuff LP in 1970, with Idris Muhammad, Lee Morgan, Hubert Laws and Buster Williams.
Sister Janie by Funk Inc on the flip — with James Brown’s Sex Machine its point of departure.

label: Numero
review: The first time out for these honey-voiced odes to domesticity — alternately buoyant and sobering — produced by Earl Wiley in Chicago in 1972.

label: Arista
review: Two disco classics — Groovin’ You’ and Till You Take My Love (with Merry Clayton) — and the blissed-out jazz-funk of Modaji, featuring Hubert Laws.

label: Atlantic
review: This top-notch vinyl reissue by Speakers Corner in Germany is mastered from the original tapes using analogue components only. So if you don’t own this almighty LP, now’s the time to strike.

label: Go Ahead
review:
Two stormers, just recently discovered and never before on vinyl. 
Donny had demoed both songs in 1966, alongside Leroy Hutson, Guy Draper and Al Johnson in a group called The Mayfield Singers. Two years later he re-recorded them with a fuller production for Atco (who shelved them).
Soulful, thumping Northern, like Stevie going to a go-go.

label: Rhino
review: Everything Is Everything, Donny Hathaway, Live, Extension Of A Man and In Performance.

release: Old Town & Barry's Deep Down & Dirty Sides
label: Kent
Vostok
review: ‘Seventeen of the choicest Maori/Polynesian soul, funk and disco tracks from Aotearoa between the afro-tastic years of 1973 to 1983. Sweet!’

label: Motown
review:
Music by Freddie Perren and Fonce Mizell; songs performed by Edwin Starr.
With Easin’ In.

label: Sol Discos
review:
Synthy, early-eighties, disco-soul floater (with a ballad on the flip) from Detroit.
Originally the first release on Hirame; then on Future Electric (under the artist name Direct Pressure).

label: Numero
review: Vintage funk and sweet soul by children, drawn from obscure 45s — fresh and irresistible, praps our favrit Numero so far.

release: The Baby Huey Story - The Living Legend
label: Curtom

release: Don't You Just Know It - The Very Best Of 1956-1962
label: Jasmine
Expansion
review: His first two LPs, from 1969 and 1970, originally released by RCA. Soul Portrait is the one. WH said he was Otis-watching, but it doesn’t really sound like it. Highlights here include Your Love Keeps Liftin’ Me Higher, Lucky To Be Loved By You, When A Boy Falls In Love and A Love That’s Worth Having (as any fan of Madlib, 50 Cent, 9th Wonder and co will testify).

label: Motown
review:
From 1974, biting Curtis and Isaac Hayes. 
The killer cuts are Ain’t That (Mellow, Mellow) and Give Me Some Of That Good Old Love.

label: Acid Jazz
review: Classic — with the great rare groove All Because Of You, the great instrumental Cool Out, the great song Lucky Fellow.

label: Curtom
review: His second LP, from 1974, featuring a nice, mellow version of The Ghetto. With Fred Reklaw and Phil Upchurch.

label: Acid Jazz
review:
An excellent overview (though a bit like shooting fish in a barrel). Tune after tune coiled into the DNA of Honest Jon’s. Don’t miss the Stevie-esque, previously unreleased Positive Forces.
Licensed from the great man himself, who dug out some precious snaps for the booklet.

label: Honest Jon's Records
review:
“We started with a cosmic idea that we were taught from a very young age – that the stars and planets make a sound, that deep in outer space there is audible harmony.” 
Book Of Sound is the brilliant, richly resonant exploration of these interstellar low ways. By turns urgent and contemplative, funky and reflective; varied in its textures, but entirely of one piece. Underpinned by cosmology, held in place by meditation, swirling with notions of history, science, theology, ancestry — this is a heady conceptual brew. But the music speaks loudest: ‘the sound of surprise’, magnificently retrieving Spiritual Jazz from the knacker’s yard.
It’s a deeply Chicagoan record. “It’s got the vibe of the lake,’ continues trombonist Cid, “the vibe of the prairies opening up to the west.” Also the Sun Ra albums recorded there in the 1950s, and — of course, being the dad of all seven ensemblists — Phil Cohran’s wonderful albums from the 1960s. 
“You know, it’s tough trying to satisfy everybody with our music. It’s hard enough satisfying ourselves, let alone the jazz scene, the hip hop guys, what have you. With this album we just dropped all that as a consideration, and tuned into deeper principles.”

release: 24 Groups Inspired By The Impressions And Curtis Mayfield
label: Kent

release: Original Stone Cold Soul, Funk And Rare Grooves
label: Strut
Get On Down
review: Crucial Arthur — with a deadly Walter Gibbons.

label: Peoples Potential Unlimited
review: New soul from South Carolina, with Maze in the upper register, and a Beautiful Swimmers mastermix on the flip.

release: Incendiary Funk And R 'N B Instrumentals 1966-1973
label: BGP
RCA
review: His third RCA LP, from 1976, is  the most soulful and laid-back, with groovy Marvin and Stevie covers, and the two-step killer I Love You. Don Blackman on lead vocals, Mchael Brecker leading the horns.

label: RCA
review: His ambitious 1974 breakthrough as leader, superbly mixing funk and jazz improvisation on a major-label recording budget, with strong political and spiritual themes, even a nod to the Duke.

label: T Neck
review: At their soulful best — with the rare groove classics Work To Do and Lay Away.

label: Now Again
review:
Blimey! The unreleased JBs album recorded by Bootsy Collins and co in 1970!
Featuring a twelve-minute version of Marva Whitney’s It’s My Thing, by way of Jimi Hendrix, The Meters and Kool & The Gang.
A coup even by Now Again standards — there are only two extant copies of the King test pressing — the music has been remastered for vinyl from the original two-track tape, and comes in a heavyweight sleeve, with a 12-page booklet of excellent notes and exclusive photos.

release: All Aboard The Soul Funky Train
label: People

release: Teenage Girl In A Changing World
label: Towne House

release: Welcome Home: The Okeh Recordings Volume 2
label: Kent
review: Sixties Chicago soul for connoisseurs, from the Okeh, Columbia and Epic labels. Carl Davis sublime at the controls, plenty Curtis songs over the two volumes.

release: It's All Over: The Okeh Recordings Volume 1
label: Kent

release: Speak Her Name: The Okeh Recordings Volume 3
label: Kent
4 Men With Beards
review: Perhaps her greatest LP, recorded at FAME in Muscle Shoals, Alabama, with Rick Hall and the gang, released by Cadet in 1968. A handful of belters, a couple of Don Covay songs, excellent interpretations of Steal Away and Otis’ Security… the marvellously sympathetic musicianship of Carl Banks, Roger Hawkins, Barry Beckett and co… and the almighty I’d Rather Go Blind.

label: Liger Vision Media
review: Mashing up classic electro hip hop, post-punk, two-step soul, rare boogie, a little Dutch psych, cosmic electronic library music, booty-bass, and jacking acid classics, Pants-style, for starters.

label: Numero
review: Early-eighties R&B. (Previously unreleased, though Charles Davis cut a version for Sutra.)

label: BGP
review: Sublime disco-soul, both sides, originally produced by Curtis Mayfield for Wand, definitively remixed by Tom Moulton for Scepter. Everyone needs these.

artist: John Ellison Of The Soul Brothers Six
release: Funky Funky Way Of Makin' Love
label: Phil L.A Of Soul

release: The M And M Mixes Volume 3
label: BBE

release: Over The Mountain; Across The Sea
label: Chess

release: Funk Beyond The Call Of Duty
label: DJM
Columbia
review: Superb 1980 soul album — classic two-step business — produced by Norman Connors, with The Jones Girls on backing vocals, and Jean Carn guesting.

release: I Love The Way You Love
label: United Artists
Numero
review:
Two sides of unreleased, vintage Minneapolis funk by the Exciters front-man. 
As with the 94 East, the flipside is exclusive to this seven.

release: Dap-Dippin' With Sharon Jones And The Dap Kings
label: Daptone

release: Give The People What They Want
label: Daptone

release: You're A Peachtree Freak On Peachtree Street
label: Peoples Potential Unlimited
Black Jazz
review: Plunky and co for Strata East.

label: SAM
review:
Cosmic disco from 1981, with a blend of driving drums, horny horns, vocodered vocals and pure sleaze which hit big at WBMX in Chicago, at the dawn of House.
K.I.D. is a certain Geoffrey Bastow from Yorkshire, surprisingly enough.

label: TK Disco
review:
Miami Sound masterwork. Monster, ecstatic, hard boogie from 1975 (eclipsing George McCrae’s original, the year before). Timeless funk; perfect lyrics. 
Biggie pitched it down and hard-boiled it, on Ready To Die…. Digital Underground snuck it into Doowutchyalike…
Check this and have another think about KC.

release: The World Of Keith Haring: Influences And Connections
label: Soul Jazz

release: Ernest Kelley Presents 25 Soul Classics From Detroit And New York
label: Grapevine
BGP
review: Superbad from start to finish, this survey of the Cincinnati label in the after-shock of Papa’s Got A Brand New Bag. Almighty James Brown productions (or knock-offs) like Honky Tonk Popcorn, Unwind Yourself and Fever. That Coasters to close… bim.

label: RCA
review:
This was a massive crossover hit for the gospel star, nudging Patrice Rushen’s original towards R&B and hip hop. 
From Tony Humphries’ Southport war-chest.

label: AA
review: Sixth volume of Kon And Amir’s Mixtape series. Two discs stuffed with hip hop breaks.

label: De-Lite Records
review: Even at their funkiest, still jazzing it up, live in a Hollywood nightclub in 1970.

label: Jazzman
review:
The idea was for this record to be sold at the door of a theatrical show at Detroit’s Bethel A.M.E. church. The show bombed, lasting just two weeks; and with only a handful of copies punted, most of the reminder were later destroyed in a basement flood. 
It’s intriguing, youthful, left-field gospel-soul. A bit odd. The deep funk of Thoughs Were The Days is the coup de grâce.
Well-presented, with notes drawing on new interviews with creative mainstays E.J. Garrison and Rhodia McAdoo.
Don’t hang about.

label: Warners
review: With their unmissable, blistering nine-minute version of the Cat Stevens, a masterpiece of cosmic, jazzy soul.

label: Favorite
review: Superb, get-down-deep disco from 1980, by one of the Thomas & Taylor duo. (Though he sounds like a dirty rascal, Lamar and Judy were married for real. You remember You Can’t Blame Love, with Patrick Adams.)

release: I Just Want To Say I Love You
label: Elf
Be With Records
review: LW’s the genius behind Marvin’s I Want You and the genie in nuff Theo and KDJ records. Here’s his two-step touchstone from 1982, featuring the bim bimmer Why I Came To California, and Somewhere, a duet with the great Flora Purim. (Airto’s on call, too.)

label: Pepite
review:
A gorgeous crossing of lovers rock, jazz-funk and soul, originally out in 1982 on Sanity Records, over in Chapel Market, Islington.
Wayne Henderson vibes — stuff like The McCrarys’ Love On A Summer’s Night, the same year — with a twist of Caribbean London.

release: I'm Caught Up (In A One Night Love Affair)
label: Prelude Records
review: Featuring Jocelyn Brown and Leroy Burgess; produced by Patrick Adams; mixed by John Morales. Utterly essential disco.

artist: Life & Death On The New York Dancefloor 1980-1983
label: Reappearing Records

artist: Life & Death On The New York Dancefloor 1980-1983
label: Reappearing Records
Numero
review: A typically lovely Numero booklet tells the story of Chicago’s only blues-funk family band with an eight-year-old drummer, from early days with J.B. Hutto to Little Ed’s final snare cracks for Southside Movement.

label: Brunswick
review: Masterful jazz vibes set to Willie Henderson’s funky arrangements of Brunswick soul — great Eugene Record compositions like Otis Leavill’s enraptured Love Uprising.

label: Superior Viaduct
review:
In truth this is just prior to the formation of Liquid Liquid, in 1981. Like a no-wave, Saturnian version of Raymond Scott’s big band. The punks at the London Musicians Collective would have loved them.
LI played various NYC lofts and clubs, including Tier 3, Mudd Club and CBGB. Audience members were encouraged to bring their own instruments along. Idiot Orchestra was an offshoot involving more than a dozen players  — clarinet, saxophone, trumpet, violin, cello, synth, bass, marimba and drums. 
With a fanzine featuring rare photos and a new interview with Richard McGuire.

release: I Like The Way You Do It
label: Peoples Potential Unlimited
Light In The Attic
review: An engaging mixture of old friends and new faces — freshly blended too, with Dylan’s George Jackson run between Elaine Brown and the Watts Prophets, Roy Harper in amongst rap poetry.

artist: Little George N' The Mixed Generation
label: Athens Of The North
review: Ace kid funk, with coolly blunted singing by the little un, and a good old-fashioned break-and-a-half.

release: Wah Wah Jazz, Funky Soul And Other Dirty Grooves
label: BGP

release: Vol. 2: More Wah Wah Jazz, Funky Soul And Other Dirty Grooves
label: BGP

release: Vol.3: Busting Out Of The Ghetto
label: BGP
Numero
review: Gospel, group soul, garage-punk, northern, jazz and funk, recorded by Felton Williams between 1967 and1981 in Ecorse, just downriver from Detroit. Amazingly the DVD contains 200 more recordings, and a film.

label: Numero
review: Local funk, gospel and soul — a splash of folk, a dash of moody indie — pressed at Boddie in Cleveland. Wicked Lester, Slippery When Wet, Berlin West and other complete unknowns, impeccably turned out by Numero.

label: Salsoul
review: Leroy Burgess’ boogie masterwork, featuring Larry Levan murder like I Know You Will and Something Else.

label: Future Days Recordings
review: Celebrating the more sophisticated, uptown productions on the label, mostly cut in New York under the supervision of soul royalty like Jerry Ragovoy, Van McCoy, George Kerr and Richard Tee. Stunners like Linda Jones’ Hypnotized and Bobby Freeman’s spooky Shadow Of Your Love; rare Realistics, Bobby Reed, Mary Lee Whitney, and Tommy Starr; and several unreleased titles, including a gem from Bob & Earl, Just One Look In Your Eyes.

release: Volume Four: Sweeter Than Sweet Things 1964-68
label: Future Days Recordings
review:
Loma was set up by Bob Krasnow at an address on Burbank in LA, overlooking Loma Avenue at the back. (He left in 1966 to set up Kama Sutra/Buddha, promptly signing Captain Beefheart’s Safe As Milk.) 
Early dabblings in R&B were a hangover from Krasnow’s time at King — and there were one-aways like Kim Fowley’s The Belfast Gipsies —  but Loma is best characterised as a Warners subsidiary, for four years expertly trained on the burgeoning soul singles market, especially rich in Northern Soul. 
The final volume of this excellent retrospective series offers plenty of unreleased material, including stars like Linda Jones and The Mighty Hannibal, dancers like The Marvellos’ I Need You and The Invincibles’ Heartstrings, and such classy exemplars of the Ragovoy-styled uptown sound as Carl Hall and Ben Aiken.

label: West End
review: Besides a 1980 promo, this version has never before made it to vinyl. More moog-bleep ravishment than the standard offering, and a little slower. Plus the freaking, uptempo, rare-as-hens-teeth instrumental mix.

release: The Soulful Gospel Of Checker Records
label: Play Back
RCA Victor
review: Terrific soulful Northern banger — a Wigan anthem — and classic Motor City fire from Jack Ashford’s Pied Piper Productions. Performed, written and produced by LC.

label: Soul Brother
review:
From 1974, featuring knockout rare groove like I Don’t Need Nobody Else and What Do You Want Me To Do. 
Limber, feeling and introspective, with full horns and strings setting fine songs and frankly soulful singing.
Lou came through in Detroit as a writer and producer with Barbara Lewis, before signing in his own right to Epic, via the Rags label run by legendary producer Jerry Ragovoy. Hereafter he was briefly a member of The Fifth Dimension.
One of the greatest of all modern soul albums.

label: Cotillion
review: Sublime soul music from 1969, produced by Jerry Wexler and Tom Dowd, with strings and horns supervised by Arif Mardin.

label: Salsoul
review: Tom Moulton and Joe Claussell mixes.

release: From A Girl's Point Of View
label: 20th Century Records
BGP
review: Japan Blues on the ones and twos.

label: Now Again
review: A tremendous compilation — soulful, searing and heavy, and beautifully documented — strongly recommended.

label: AVI
review:
Lowrell from The Lost Generation, for Liberace’s AVI imprint in 1979.
With the classic Mellow Mellow Right On, as sampled across the board, from Massive Attack to Common.

label: Salsoul
review:
Utterly brilliant, spaced-out, jazzy, left-field disco, mixed by Walter Gibbons.
Moon Maiden, on the flip, is a stupendous Duke Ellington cover: ‘almost nine minutes of frantic, trippy disco eccentricity with soaring strings, odd analogue synth frequencies and spooky vocals flowing in and out… driven along by wooden blocks, cowbells and that insistent bass-line.’ 
Only available previously as a run of promos; never fully released till now.

label: Kent
review: ‘The Complete Tribe And Jet Stream Singles 1966-1979.’ Including the original version of You Left The Water Running.

release: I'm Gonna Run Away From You
label: Atco

release: Tell Me What's Wrong With The Men
label: BGP
review: Magnificent, smoking sister-funk, both sides. ‘What is wrong with the men / Trying to do us in.’ Produced by West Coast legend Miles Grayson.

label: Get On Down
review: The JBs by another name, with the massive Cross The Track (We Better Go Back) – which used to go off like a bomb at Shake ‘n’ Fingerpop — and the shuffling funk of Boogie ‘N’ Twist.

artist: Maceo And All The Kings Men
label: House Of The Fox

release: Um, Um, Um, Um, Um, Um
label: Okeh
AJP
review: The Bonanza Ska trombonist turning his hand to street funk for Ahmad Jamal’s AJP imprint in 1970. Heavy input from Monty Alexander. Like full-on early Fatback Band subtly spiced with ska and reggae. CD from BGP.

release: You Made The Rain Fall Down
label: T-A

artist: Marie Adams And The Three Tons Of Joy
label: Command Performance

artist: Marie Knight With The Sam Price Trio
label: Brunswick
La Shawn
review: Ravishing, luminous boogie from 1980. High-steppin’ horns; reggae-sauced bass; terrific, down-home, gospelized singing. Bomb.

label: Chiaroscuro
review: This talisman of spiritual, rare-groove jazz is an ecstatic fusion of Stevie and Ubiquity, with the mystical charge and dancefloor clout of stuff like Places And Spaces, Shifting Gears, Music Is My Sanctuary…

label: Buddah
review: Featuring Curtis’ own swirling production of his title-song. (Babs is more soft-porny than Sisters Love.) Otherwise mostly Sigma recordings staffed by Leon Huff, Norman Harris, Earl Young, Vince Montana…

label: Jazzman
review: All previously unreleased, from band-leader Fred Shorts’ personal archive: modern soul, seventies groovers, mid-tempo crossover dancers, and high energy funk from Chicago, 1973-84. No filler.

label: Kent
review: Numerous rarities and unissued gems, together with all her best sides: the essential Maxine Brown. Classic soul music from heaven.

release: There's No Place Like America Today
label: Charly
Curtom
review:
Many people rate this his best solo album, for murder like Pusherman, Freddie’s Dead and Give Me Your Love (and less persuasively because it trespassed most deeply into rock audiences). 
‘This heavy script… I could relate with a lot of it… It allowed me to get past the glitter of the drug scene and go to the depth of it — allowing a little bit of the sparkle and the highlights lyrically, but always with a moral to that.’
CD with extras, from Snapper. It won’t be a tenner for long (as Pusherman might say).

release: Keep On Keeping On: Curtis Mayfield Studio Albums 1970-1974
label: Rhino
review: Curtis (1970), Roots (1971), Back to the World (1973) and Sweet Exorcist (1974), newly remastered. The LPs come individually sleeved, in a slipcase; 180g vinyl.

release: In The Music... The Village Never Ends
label: Be With Records
review: The opener Sweet Juju was a hard-sought West London two-step weapon, in the day; Nomalizo is tropical funk, somewhere between Maze’s Twilight and Ramsey Lewis’ Brazilica, beloved by the neo-Dingwalls massive.

label: Reel Music
review: Southern soul from her Columbia years, pre TK (but with Steve Alaimo producing, already). Killers like Lead Me On. Her voice never sounded better.

label: Cat
review:
Storming out of the traps with All This Love That I’m Givin’, this killer LP was always very hard to find in its original issue (reputedly because a fire destroyed most of the run). 
CD from Cherry Red.

label: Buddah
review:
Superb disco boogie. A deeply soulful song, expertly sung. Killer, bare-bones break-downs, soaring strings, resplendent horns, with composers McFadden and Whitehead rocking the controls. 
Plus an unmissable version of Curtis’ Make Me Believe in You! Fabulous, epic, Van McKoy drama, with a meaner Melba, thumping bass and stomping kick-drum.

artist: Harold Melvin And The Blue Notes
label: Philadelphia International
Limelight
review: Eddie Harris’ bassist with an effects box and such guests as Lester Bowie and Phil Upchurch, vibeing it up like Charles Stepney, those Ramsey Lewis Cadets, or even early Earth, Wind And Fire.

release: The City's Funk And Soul In The Decade After Otis, 1968-1978
label: BGP
Numero
review: George Bowman’s blues-funk from late-sixties Arizona, crossing Hendrix and James Brown, with Dyke And The Blazers drummer Rodney Brown passing the peas in fine style.

release: Soul, Funk And Jazzy Grooves From Mainstream Records
label: BGP

release: Nothing Like Dat Funky Funky Music
label: Aloha Got Soul
Aloha Got Soul
review: The crown jewels of Hawaiian funk, from 1980 — with an open, upful ‘island sound’ attuned to the spaced-out, mystical vibe of classic, late-seventies Roy Ayers, Gary Bartz and co. Last few.

release: Bring It On Home To Me
